summary: After 12 years of bucolic bliss, Mr. Fox (George Clooney) breaks a promise to his wife (Meryl Streep) and raids the farms of their human neighbors, Boggis, Bunce and Bean. Giving in to his animal instincts endangers not only his marriage but also the lives of his family and their animal friends. When the farmers force Mr. Fox and company deep underground, he has to resort to his natural craftiness to rise above the opposition.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is a true masterpiece, with a charming and witty script that's brought to life through stunning stop-motion animation. The film's whimsical and surrealist style, coupled with Wes Anderson's precise directorial touch, creates a truly unique viewing experience. The voice cast, led by George Clooney as the titular character, delivers some of the most memorable and hilarious performances in recent memory. The characters are all lovable, each with their own quirks and personalities that bring the story to life. The film's score, composed by Alexandre Desplat, perfectly captures the film's adventurous spirit. The attention to detail in the animation is astounding, with every frame bursting with texture and color. The pacing of the film is also perfect, with a narrative that keeps you engaged from start to finish. Overall, Fantastic Mr. Fox is a true cinematic gem and a must-watch for all ages.

American auteur Wes Anderson takes his free-wheeling live action style and successfully adapts it to his first animated feature, Fantastic Mr. Fox.  After promising Mrs. Fox (Meryl Streep) that he will no longer steal poultry from the henhouse, Mr. Fox (George Clooney) is unable to resist his animal instincts and eventually finds himself in a life and death battle with three farmers, all of whom are committed to ending the thefts.  The stop action animation is absolutely stunning throughout, filled with minute detail from start to finish.  Cleverly written and ably performed by a cast of Anderson regulars (Bill Murray, Owen Wilson, Jason Schwartzman, etc.), it really is an animated film like no other, filled with clever humor and interesting set pieces, all economically crammed into a tight eighty-seven minute running time.

For those who are looking for a 100% faithful adaptation of Roald Dahl's book, I think they will be disappointed. Lacking the dark edge of Dahl's book and of his writing in general, Fantastic Mr Fox is not so good as an adaptation, however on its own terms it is wonderful. It is an endearing and hugely enjoyable film.

One thing that stood out was how the film looked. Instead of the CGI rendered effects, Wes Anderson opts for a more old-fashioned stop-motion effect. This decision worked, because the visual look is outstanding, not just in the beautifully detailed backgrounds and sets but in how the characters move as well and the small details such as the armchair in his writing hut.

I like Alexandre Desplat's music quite a bit. His score for Fantastic Mr Fox is no exception, it is quirky yet still has the minimalist style that makes Desplat stand out. The story is sometimes slow in the pace but because of the humour and how it looked, I never found the film boring, besides the story itself is so good. The writing is great, the humour is more adult but a vast majority of it is very funny with the odd touching moment too.

The characters add a lot. Mr Fox is one of my favourite titular characters in a book and the film did little to change that, and while some are slightly underused they serve their purpose well. The voice work is fantastic. I wasn't sure about George Clooney, but he does do a bravura job, and Meryl Streep is quite touching. Michael Gambon is sterling, as is Bill Murray as Badger.

In conclusion, hugely enjoyable and one of my personal favourites of 2009. 9/10 Bethany Cox

As a child reading the classic Roald Dahl books, I imagined how absolutely fantastic and cozy the nights must've been with Mr. Fox, as I read about the days of promised success and the breath-stopping suspense visual of Mr. Fox sneaking and digging vigorously with his team. Reminiscing back on this fantastic experience back, I have to admit that I may have approached this movie with hopes a little bit too high. For example, when Mr. Fox was buying a new home, he encountered a strange badger that seemed to blank out in the oddest of ways, which was sort of unsettling. Not only this, but Mr. Fox has continuously made use of strange terms such as "You cussin' with me?" or that peevish snap and a whistle (which is apparently his "signature move" or supposed "trademark"). However, I have to give the movies huge props for extending the plot, since in the story they left the reader hanging worrying about how long the hunters waited for the animals to come out. Overall, I wouldn't recommend it to my friends because there are tremendously quirky aspects of this film that normal people - if anybody - will ever understand first hand. Maybe I'm just not brilliant enough in the liberal arts to process what the film directors were thinking when they made Mr. Fox, but maybe I'm not the only one that would think this way.

A good time for children because they love anything with animated characters but for us adults, Fantastic Mr. Fox becomes a beloved comfort film one will rewatch many times with its stunning animation, a well-written screenplay with sarcastic, dry and witty humor, perfect voice actors, and overall, interesting and loving plot. It is so exhilarating seeing common messages of life (such as perseverance, acceptance, family and friendship, survival, overcoming obstacles, etc) being portrayed in a refreshing way that avoids the toothache and overload of cheese. A continued appreciation for the sheer dedication of Wes Anderson. The love and devotion he puts in his films pays off and shines bright. For me, this has officially become the top Anderson film, dethroning Isles of Dogs and The Grand Budapest Hotel. What the cuss?!?!

I only gave it two stars because they did a decent job with the animation. I won't compare it with the Roald Dahl book which I never read, but it doesn't make a difference, The movie was charmless and so bland and boring I bailed after twenty minutes. I doubt even little kids would enjoy this.

So what happens? Mr. and Mrs. Fox are at a farm, first conversing, then stealing a squab from it. Then Mr. Fox sees a trap and gets curious and ends up trapping himself and his wife in it. Then all of a sudden, two years pass (no explanation of how they got out of the trap) and they have an adolescent son, then they have a young cousin visit when his father is ill. In the meantime, Mr. Fox got a job in the newspapers and they move from their old hole into a tree home, even though they are located near disreputable farmers.

My description makes the movie sound more interesting than it actually was. Where there should have been laughs and/or excitement, there are none. Everything is done in such a bland and blah way, even the puppets seemed like they were bored and wished they were somewhere else. Not for kids, adults, or anybody else, unless they need assistance in falling asleep.

I've not always responded well to Wes Anderson films - I think that's more about personal preference than a fault with him - but I found this more accessible than many of his others that I've seen to date. It felt like the ideal marriage of style and medium; the precision of the animation a good fit for Anderson's trademark attention to detail, and I laughed consistently throughout the film where usually with this director my amusement tends to lag in the second half. Lovely, warm, funny.

Fantastic Mr. Fox: A Work of Art.
This week I watched the highly enjoyable film, Fantastic Mr. Fox. Directed by Wes Anderson and adapted by him from the book by Roald Dahl, it also stars George Clooney, Meryl Streep, Jason Schwartzman and Bill Murray. The film tells the story of Mr. Fox and his family and their attempt to evade the farmers Boggin, Bunce, and Bean who seek to kill Mr. Fox for stealing their crops. The thing that struck me most about this film and the thing I was fully expecting to strike me going in was the immense amount of color and craft that went into the visuals of this film. This Movie is truly a work of art in every sense of the word. Every scene is packed full of insane detail and color all of which is handcrafted in every respect. It's almost off putting at the beginning the unique and original style that the film presents. The film opens on a signature Wes Anderson symmetrical wide shot that, while having ample dead space, features a single tree at the center that sits atop a round hill where Mr. Fox is standing and eating an apple in the orange light of sunset. The quick jerky movements of his character display for all to see that this film is animated with stop motion. Each character handmade and moved frame by frame on a miniature set to display the action. All throughout the film we move from one gorgeous set to another and with Anderson's unique style of cinematography catch the action in a fun and artistic way that is not hindered by the constraints that stop motion usually present. The colors and characters provide a life to the film that is all its own. The thing that can be said most about this film is the way it really does stand apart if only for the incredibly unique and beautiful way it tells its equally unique story. There is, however, more to the film than that. Even though the movie is like looking at a masterpiece in multiple arts at the same time for eighty minutes and even though it's made for children and is lighthearted and comical, the film does have substance under the show that shines from behind the visuals and makes them all the more radiant. Simply a joy to look at and full of humor and family values, Fantastic Mr. Fox is not just an example of how kid's movies should be made, but is a gold standard of how great films can be made.
The thing that really stands out about Fantastic Mr. Fox is its chaotic and colorful world that only Wes Anderson could provide. My mind was blown away by the amount of movement and detail in every frame of the film and especially in the long tracking shots and many other unique angles that it explores. Stop motion animation is not an easy thing to pull off in general but it seems that Anderson was born for it. Even in his live action films the action on screen is very deliberate and explosive; with each movement and line of dialogue carefully timed to create the right flow in the scene. In the stop motion medium, Anderson is able to use this style to the full and in typical fashion completely sells the odd nature of the film we are watching. He also takes the opportunity to saturate Mr Fox's world with rich colors and intricate design and artistry. Not a single frame is boring to look at and each one is a work of art in its own right. The opening shot (as I mentioned before) the apple cellar and the sewer waterfall are all excellent examples of how much craftsmanship and care was put into making these tiny models and sets really come to life. As if the match between Wes and stop motion wasn't clear enough, even his signature style of Cinematography blends perfectly with the medium. With long symmetrical wide shots and perfectly horizontal tracking shots, Anderson's style lets the animation really speak for itself with frames full of color, action and artistry while still lending an attitude of quirkiness to the camerawork that every other aspect of the film has in droves. Unlike many pioneering films, Fantastic Mr Fox is not hindered by the massive amount of work and innovation that went into its creation but embraces its style, with all its pros and cons, to the full and thus creates an experience that works on all levels.
As for theme, I think I need to say before anything else that this movie is just plain ridiculous. Everything it says or tries to say is done tongue and cheek or with a punchline. As lite family entertainment it doesn't really push a message to the forefront (the closest it gets is the subplot about Ash being "different" and how that's ok) but like all good stories, it does present some interesting Ideas that can and should be considered. At the center of the story is Mr Fox (obviously) who finds himself going up against his own primal instincts. At the very start of the film, Mr and Mrs Fox stage a heist together and they get caught. When Mrs Fox rather casually reveals that she is pregnant and requests that he find a "new line of work" the film cuts to two years later where Mr Fox lives peacefully with his wife and son in an underground house and is now a columnist for a newspaper. He expresses a wish to live again to his wife and mentions that he wants to buy a house above ground since he won't have much more time to live. This is the first in a series of "rebellions" that Mr Fox stages in order to relive the days before he became domesticated. All goes well at first and he robs the first two farmers with no issue and he keeps telling his partner Kylie that he'll stop after the next robbery. However the second robbery causes the three farmers, Boggin, Bunce and Bean to lie in wait for Mr Fox and they spring on him while he re-enters his house. Mr Fox escapes minus a tale but the farmers resolve to dig him out and kill him once and for all. This causes the entire animal community to go underground into the sewers to hide. Mr Fox must learn to do what he should rather than what he wants to do. Even though it seemed to be paying off to go back into a life of stealing (the animal community even resorts to stealing after going underground) it causes much danger and inconvenience for all those around Mr Fox. Mr Fox never really does learn his lesson about stealing (the film ends with him and his family robbing a grocery store) what he does learn is that reliving the past is not worth jeopardizing what one has in the present. In a way, Mr Fox must go against his primal instinct to be wild and wandering to live a life of domestication in order to protect his family. It parallels, in its own unique way, a mid-life crisis story (one can make comparisons between Mr Fox and Mr Incredible in the Incredibles for instance) but though that is the core conflict of the film, the truth of the matter is that the movie is there to have a good time and man does it deliver.
For the protagonist and antagonists of the story, their actions are based intrinsically on their wants. Mr Fox wants to feel alive again after 12 fox years of calm domesticity and it's only after an all out war with Borgin, Bunce and Bean that he realises his mistakes and comes around to being devoted to those around him instead of thinking of himself. As a polar opposite are the three antagonists: Borgin, Bunce and Bean who start out similarly motivated by their wants but their want is to kill Mr Fox for good so he can no longer steal their crops. Again with a tongue in cheek attitude the film depicts their relentless battle against Mr Fox which includes digging a giant hole where his house stood, laying siege to that hole and literally holding his nephew Kristofferson hostage. Even though their actions are over the top ruthless they still display what a juggernaut desire can be and how dangerous it can get. When someone is willing to do anything to get what they want then they are in a rather dangerous position in life that might cause them to do terrible things. In between this central conflict are Mrs Fox and Ash. Mrs Fox, more than her husband initially, provides the noble want that stands in contrast to the three farmers. She does everything she can to provide for the well being of her family and provides a moral compass for Mr Fox. He knows he isn't following this compass when he performs his first robbery and thus hides the fact from his wife until the secret finally comes out. When it does, Mrs Fox provides for her husband the questions of introspection that ultimately bring him to the right and final course. Ash is the moody and reclusive son of the Foxes. Dubbed as "different" in the very first scene with him, at first he seems like he just wants to be left alone, especially when his "perfect" cousin Kristofferson comes to stay. As we get to know the character better however, it becomes clear that he doesn't want to be different. He wants to be as good as his father and his cousin in whack bat, he wants to join his father on his heists and he doesn't want to be little. His Mother and his Father explain to him near the end that there is nothing wrong with being different, it doesn't make him worse than everyone else and being unique is a strength not a weakness. Ash even gets his own little payoff when his being little helps him to save his cousin from captivity. Bolstered by a strong cast and masterful character animation, this is a film with a real core and compelling, if not oddly quirky, characters.
Fantastic Mr Fox is good clean fun but also a dazzling work of art. These two elements, so rarely coupled together, put it at masterpiece status. It is a masterclass in the art of stop motion, with each element meticulously handcrafted to create a film incredibly unique and simply a joy to drink in. Colorful, snappy and even stylish, tiny details and brilliant composition abound throughout the film. As a kids movie, the messages or deeper meanings are not in focus but that makes them all the more poignant when discovered and discussed. Not quite an allegory while still not being quite applicable in subject matter to real life, it exists primarily as a fairy tale and plays the part masterfully. The characters are larger than life and delightful, filling up each frame with vivacity and life. The diverse and colorful voice cast complete the picture by adding a special kind of animation all of their own that is so pivotal to stop motion. Fantastic Mr Fox is art. Somewhat high art admittedly but it is so full of charm and life that anyone, even a child, can connect with it and all ages and people can appreciate its appeal. It is truly timeless and a masterpiece that all can enjoy.
For this film, I've got to say that 3 stars do not mean 'meh, it passed the time' as RT seems to suggest: no, it's undoubtedly a fun film, which is inventive and witty, without ever becoming tiring.

Finally finishing Wes Anderson's filmography, I decided that I would rent Fantastic Mr. Fox. I watched it in the movie theatre when it initially came out, however, honestly, I didn't remember any of it. So, I finally rented it and put it on, and what a ride. The movie is really fun, I've never read the Roald Dahl novel, but that really didn't bother me. Being a children's movie, the plot was whimsical and fun, but it also had some very prominent adult themes. Being a fox in a world straight out of a fairy tale, but also being able to add in the element of a mundane average life being flipped on its head is really what this film is. Being Wes Anderson's first animated feature, it's easy to see how he translates his typical visual style into the animated medium. The voice acting is great and the plot makes for a fun take on the heist format. Still, somehow, all of that doesn't help the movie from some of my big problems with it. Although the plot is fun, I felt that some of the emotional beats didn't work, I have noticed that this has somehow become one of my largest problems with Wes Anderson't movies. Some of the character arcs didn't come to the right conclusion either, and being a fan of strong characters, this did annoy me, as the characters were great at the beginning. But cuss it, the movie was a lot of fun, and I'm really glad I watched it. 8.7/10

Wes Anderson's stop motion caper is creative, cool, and so much fun. His tale of a former thief struggling to find a foothold in mundane life is amusing and the titular character is brought to life by George Clooney, a perfect fit. The stop motion animation flows incredibly smooth and all the character and sets look organically crafted. The same is said for the villainous humans who, in proper Wes Anderson form, are just people trying to live their lives and dealing with a desk who is harming their industries. Deep character moments, fantastic supporting cast and characters, and many inner conflicts make this a more mature animated adventure, and a true Wes Anderson film. This is one of my favorite animated films.

"Fantastic Mr. Fox," is a great piece of stop-motion animation by Wes Anderson. Anderson is known for having a unique flare in filmmaking with his bright colors, witty dialogue, and memorable characters. This entry in his filmography is no different. Based on the book by Roald Dahl, the movie captures much of the charm from Dahl's writing. George Clooney, Meryl Streep, Bill Murray, and Jason Shwartzman lead a great voice cast that enhance their characters with their ability to deliver their lines so well. The dialogue is charming and hilarious. The choice to replace every curse word with "cuss" made for some funny moments and is one of the more memorable things in this movie. The story is about a fox who gets into trouble by deciding to fall back on old habits. This movie is fun and the plot moves along nicely. There is really never a dull moment in this picture. The pacing is great and everything seems to have a pay-off by the end of the movie. Mr. Fox's son, Ash, might have the most change as he comes to accept himself as he is, but also that he can still do athletic things even if they aren't as great as his father or cousin. His change is what I thought was most impactful. It is a bit of a downer that the main character, Mr. Fox, isn't overly fantastic or interesting though. All he does is cause trouble and really doesn't see any consequences to his actions that are permanent (other than tail loss). The animation, done by stop-motion, is great. I'm not sure how many images there are in this movie, but there has to be an insane amount because every little movement in the characters or scenery is an image and there is a lot of motion throughout the movie. This movie is a fun one to watch. This movie is very good, but it does fall a bit short of fantastic. Overall, I give this movie an 8/10.

Wes Anderson's stop motion animated comedy film Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009) is a joyful family feature for everyone. Wes plays off of the Western and heist genres. The whistles and snaps in Alexandre Desplat's score are straight out of Western music with the empty street encounter showdowns as well. Anderson takes Roald Dahl's delight's children's book and brings it to life with resplendent claymation and adorable optimism. Fantastic Mr. Fox is a story about love of family and achieving your potential. I think any child could learn about working together and communicating your feelings better like Mr. Fox. It's a wonderful kids movie and a fine piece of filmmaking from Wes.

Wes Anderson's direction is stellar with fast pacing and silly humor for this pleasant 87 minute picture. Wes Anderson and Noah Baumbach's script is full of clever references and criticisms of capitalist farmers with no regard for the animal life surrounding them. I love how the animals talk. They're personified, so that viewers can relate to their family drama regardless of their furry state of being. Tristan Oliver's cinematography matches Anderson's early symmetrical framing and with plenty of fun wide shots. I like the brave close-up shots that showcase how detailed the puppets are in fur and eye realism. Their expressions are lifelike to people. I really have to hand it to Wes' animation team. They crafted one of the greatest animated features ever.

George Clooney is brilliant as the sly Mr. Fox. His sense of humor and good nature come across his splendid voice work as the lead wild animal in Wes Anderson's magical little comedy. Clooney plays Mr. Fox as completely cool and calculating like he's Danny Ocean with fur. Meryl Streep is phenomenal as Felicity Fox with her stern mood, rising temper, and tender affection as Mr. Fox's beloved wife. Jason Schwartzman is fun as the moody and jealous Ash Fox. Bill Murray is excellent as the scolding Clive Badger. Willem Dafoe is strange and threatening as the complex Rat. 

Furthermore, I like the relaxed Owen Wilson as the passive aggressive Coach Skip. Wallace Wolodarsky as the shy and steadfast opossum. Eric Chase Anderson is excellent as the skillful natural Kristofferson Silverfox. Michael Gambon is fearsome as the cruel farmer Franklin Bean. Wes Anderson himself is fun as the real estate agent Stan Weasel. Juman Malouf, Wes' wife, is sweet as the quiet Agnus the fox. Roman Coppola is the squirrel contractor and Brian Cox cameos as the reporter's voice. Who else could you want? How about Adrien Brody as an adorable field mouse?
Fantastic movie, no pun intended, from Wes Anderson!! Thriving with its animation, humor, voice cast and themes, this is a top-notch animated film.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is one of the funniest animated movies I have seen in a while. Although it appears the target audience is children in my opinion it is better suited for adults. Don't worry, there is nothing in this movie that is inappropriate for kids but, if you are looking for a typical Disney movie for family time this might not be the best choice. With a realistic animation style and a washed-out color scheme you might find it difficult to maintain a child's attention. But if you are an adult looking for a fun movie to watch I think you have found your film. As mentioned before the setting of the film and the characters are different than the soft featured animation done by DreamWorks or Pixar. The almost realistic look of the animals in the film might be a little too much for a small child to handle. This paired with a dull and desolate setting might prove to be boring for some children. Aside from the visual side of the film some of the topics in the movie are more relatable to adults. Examples are things such as Mr. Fox having a financial and legal advisor that is addressed several times throughout the film and several instances of inebriation. This movie addresses several big topics as well such as deforestation, unplanned pregnancies, and possible LGBTQ+ issues depending on the viewers interpretation. Lastly the over all theme of the movie is about Mr. Fox and his need to live among the elite which ultimately leads to the destruction of his family and the relapse of a kleptomaniac lifestyle.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is a 2009 animated film directed by one of my all time favourite directors Wes Anderson. The film stars George Clooney as Mr. Fox and Jason Schwartzman as Ash.

The voice acting in my opinion is really strong. I personally don't very much like George Clooney, but I have to say that he does one of his best performances yet as the fantastic Mr. Fox.

The characters like the voice acting are also really strong and memorable. I also personally really like the villains Boggis, Bunce, Bean and Rat.

The cinematography like most of Wes Anderson's films is very good with some really nice shots of the characters and scenery.

The animation in my opinion is great and really vibrant. The animation also works incredibly well with the style of the film.

The film also has some very sound and beautifully designed settings from a tree house to various farms.

Like most of Wes Anderson's films the style is exemplary from the colour scheme to the character design. 

The film also has some very sound and violent action especially for a children's film.

The dialogue in my opinion like most of Wes Anderson's films is delivered really well with great timing.

The music is also really strong and fits with the film extremely well.

The story though changed from the original story by Roald Dahl is still very strong and enjoyable to watch fold out.

Wes Anderson in my opinion has a great way with comedy and it shows here. From the jokes to the timing the comedy is pulled off near perfectly.

The film at points also has some really good atmosphere.

The film I also think is incredibly enjoyable and something I could watch everyday and never get bored with.

Over all I think this film is a masterpiece. Over all I give it a

Fantastic Mr. Fox is a masterpiece of cinema. I do not indulge in many Wes Anderson films but this however is an exception. It gives hope to the future of stop-motion and will hold up forever. The cinematography is absolutely phenomenally creative and beautiful throughout as well as the lighting and use of stop-motion elements. Everything is stop motion, from the smoke to the water; you would never notice. It is all of the small details that happen simultaneously that make it feel so real. The cast brings so much emotion to the characters and George Clooney and Meryl Streep do a beautiful job playing a fox that is both civilized and (wait for it) a wild animal.

The chapter names as well are a nice reference back to the book.

I really liked the way this was presented, the camera angles and the music definitely made this movie unique, and the design of the Claymation was very well-detailed made this movie a top notch film. The story is very good, focusing on a sly fox who loves crime and money but also has a family to take care of really puts heart into it. The characters are funny and the voice acting was really good, making the clay animals come to life with passion and finesse. I was never bored throughout but this movie isn't a masterpiece, there were some slow parts where the characters don't really talk, they just looked at each other or off into the distance.  But anyway, very cute movie.

I often find the jokes in movies geared towards a younger audience boring, predictable, and unfunny (though, that is to be expected), but the ones in this film are original, unpredictable, and overall funny. The animation isn't incredible, but I still love the style, and wish more studios made films this way. My favorite parts of this movie, however, are the characters; I love them all, and they all feel like real people (personally, I like Ash and Kristofferson the most).
Overall, this movie is fantastic, and is great to watch if you're a 24 year-old looking for lighthearted movies to watch yourself, or if you're a parent looking for a good family movie.

The writing is sharp, to- the-point and explicit with tiny tactics installed in here that not only is infomercial but hilarious too. Such dysfunctional family might have been familiar to the audience but with a perspective like this, the clock starts from zero. 

It is rich on technical aspects like its up beating background score, amazing songs, metaphorical cinematography and fine editing that paints the picture brighter. The voice cast fills in perfectly in this wild world and has done a hilarious work especially by Clooney, Streep, Murray and Wilson. 

Anderson's strong script matches its brilliant execution where you know that you have surrendered to his surreal world when he draws out emotions from these characters and pours it like rain over the audience. The three dimensional characters, satirical humor, moral conflicts and thought provoking policy that is genuinely effective are the high points of the feature.

Though I occasionally had issues with how the characters seem to at times, especially the titular character, not have any facial expressions and can only express their feelings with their eyes and for our hero a forced smile occasionally, Fantastic Mr. Fox still shows that even directors more experienced in live-action can direct a surprisingly good animated movie. With most of the books I read at home back when I was in seventh grade as you Americans call it being written by the late Roald Dahl otherwise known by Screen Junkies as "Creepy Dr. Seuss", I wanted to see the film adaptation of the book. Back then, all I saw was a decent comedy that ended far too quickly and managed to extend its source material to great new heights without succumbing to what I like to call "The Dr. Seuss Movie Curse". Now that I've grown up a bit I notice it has a more adult-oriented apporach with still enough charm to appeal to children. This movie and Coraline were actually refreshing movies to watch in 2009 since we got to take a break from CGI for a while. There were actually some really great shots thanks to the fewer limitations of animation. It sometimes even feels like a 2D side-scrolling video game. The movie's funny with slapstick jokes such as Mr. Fox and his opossum friend to dialogue-based jokes an example of which is Bill Murray's description of the three bad guy farmers and Advertised Extra Owen Wilson describing a fictional sport with complicated rules. And George Clooney nails it as Mr. Fox. He really does, I'm not saying that just to be polite or anything. Since this is my first Wes Anderson movie, I can't praise his sense of humour as heavily as in his other movies. So, if I were to write a definition for this movie in Urban Dictionary, what would I say? Fantastic Mr. Fox: A stop-motion movie released in 2009 that no one saw because...it's not CGI, I guess? Which is a shame because the movie's hilarious with a clever plot, witty humour and great voice-acting with George Clooney doing a great job at delivering a "click-click" noise that serves as the Fox's trademark. If you haven't watched it, go see it now. And I have severe doubts that reading the book will make you say "THIS MOVIE FREAKIN' SUCKS!!!" after watching the movie for a second time. Satisfaction guaranteed.

Wes Anderson's great direction mixed with surprisingly good animation with fantastic voice acting by the entire cast but mostly Clooney, Streep, and Schwartzman leads to, in my opinion, the BEST Roald Dahl based movie out there!

Fantastic Mr. Fox is directed and co-written by Wes Anderson, and it stars George Clooney, Meryl Streep, and Jason Schwartzman in a stop-motion animated film about a fox that move his family over to a big tree that's surrounded by 3 people that want to kill the fox for stealing their products. When I was at the city library, trying to copy something, I realize that I should rent some movies that I wouldn't be able to watch on TV unless it's actually now playing them. So I got myself some Sofia Coppola films and some Christian films as I heard they are terrible, and I wanted to torture myself for fun. Then I tried to think of another film to watch, and once I was thinking of my best friend, I knew that I wanted to rent this movie as this is one of her favorites, and I haven't seen this in a long time. So of course I watched this first, and I find this a lot of fun to watch. The voice acting is fantastic in this, which is kind of funny to see George Clooney and Bill Murray's characters go at each other by just growling at them. The animation is amazing that even the big things that it does in this film look so simple and easy, which I know that the animators worked very hard on it, and the effects show in this. The characters are very enjoyable to watch, especially Kylie who's played by Wallace Wolodarsky, which I didn't know he was an actor as he's a writer in some of the early Simpsons episodes, and wrote the third Wimpy Kid movie, and he plays the main character's accomplice which he sometimes just stand there dazing and not paying attention, which always makes me laugh for some reason. The script by Wes Anderson and Noah Baumbach is very witty and hilarious that I was enjoying almost every second of this film, and it didn't felt quirky for the sake of being quirky and nothing else. Fantastic Mr. Fox is an excellent film that is probably one of my favorite stop-motion animated films.

Fantastic Mr Fox is a charming & admirable children's film; its script is both its biggest strength and weakness. The stop-motion animation in Fantastic Mr Fox is first class. It's visually entertaining and packed with universally appealing comedy. Fantastic Mr Fox's script really challenges kids and entertains adults. It's how all kids films should be, but does get carried away with itself at times. At times it's so fast that some gags go over everyone's heads, because they come at such a relentless pace. Fantastic Mr Fox is authentic, creative, & most importantly, tons of fun. It's a whirlwind of a kids film that challenges and entertains.

I still have significant issues with Wes Anderson and the way he tells stories. There's this matter-of-fact way that people behave and talk that is off-putting to me. I can't count the number of times someone just tells you exactly what they are doing or are planning to do. And whenever something out of the ordinary occurs there is rarely a reaction, everyone behaves as if every moment is exactly what they expected. The one good thing about this style is that it prepared me so that I wasn't in the least bit surprised when the humans and animals just started communicating with each other as if they all spoke the same language. 

There were some humorous moments in Fantastic Mr. Fox that did work for me. I laughed occasionally at the physical humor and some of the running gags. I should also give a lot of credit to the skill that I know it took to make the stop-motion animation work. I've never been the biggest fan of how stop motion looks, and this is probably my least favorite ever. The fur on the animals looked scratchy like everything is made out of straw. I'd rather look at old Rankin/Bass Christmas specials than this stuff. Still I recognize the art that goes into this style of film. It takes so much talent and patience, so I feel like a jerk for not loving it. 

The story of Fantastic Mr. Fox worked better for me than Wes Anderson's typical movie. It seemed a little more clear cut and there were actual motivations for all the characters that made sense. I just wish I liked the characters more. I mean, Mr. Fox might be on my list of least sympathetic protagonists ever. I don't think there's a single thing he does in this movie that redeems him for me. They certainly try to make us forgive him, but it never worked for me. Then his son, Ash, is a jealous bully. That also makes me want to scream. So, a strong story with some effective humor, but with unlikable main characters and odd style. I'd say Fantastic Mr. Fox is definitely not a film for me.

Wes Anderson directs a film based on Roald Dahl's book Fantastic Mr. Fox. Clooney voices Mr. Fox who is a master of stealing chickens from farmers. When he is closed to being caught and finds out his wife is pregnant he promises to give it up. He moves to a dangerous part of town, and finds himself unable to resist trying to steal from 3 dangerous farmers (Boggis, Bunch and Bean) that live near by. After a successful heist the farmers wage war on the foxes and want to catch them at any cost, putting all the animals near by in danger. Making a full feature film out of a children's book is always challenging, but he film is well directed and really well packaged in a manner that only Wes Anderson can. The film features many of the typical Wes Anderson characters including Bill Murray, Owen Wilson and Jason Schwartzman.

So colorful and witty, not to mention stylish and unique; Wes Anderson's "Fantastic Mr. Fox" is an achievement in both storytelling and in stop motion animation. The characters were all funny and eccentric in their own ways. For those enjoy constant witty banter, this film is good for you. However, for children, it might be boring for them.

Here is a film that may have flown under your radar - a whimsical masterpiece from the master of whimsy, featuring George Clooney in what has to be some of the best voice acting work ever in an animated film.

If it weren't for the excellent casting of George Clooney as the titular Mr. Fox, this movie might not have been as enjoyable as it was. The distinctive quirkiness of Wes Anderson's direction suits the material just fine, but because the movie is populated with Anderson-esque characters of dubious morality, it's tough to care about anyone, with the exception of Mr. Fox. An animated film done by a live-action director serves to showcase how style can become a gimmick. While Woody Allen didn't direct Antz, it was still a Woody Allen film, and it was harder to watch than the vastly superior A Bug's Life. As far as Fantastic Mr. Fox is concerned, it's ok to sit through once, but I don't think kids or adults (unless they're Wes Anderson fanatics) will sit for repeat viewings.

Mr. Fox (Clooney) used to enjoy his adventurous life as a food-stealer with Ms. Fox (Streep), but now he is a suave columnist, they have a son Ash (Schwartzman), and lead a quiet life living underground. Nevertheless, as a wild animal, Mr. Fox cannot reconciled to the quiet life which Ms. Fox urges him to hew to, he purchases a new tree house regardless of his lawyer Mr. Badger (Murray)s persuasion because three meanest human farmers are living nearby. Later Mr. Foxs teenage nephew Kristofferson (Eric Chase Anderson) comes to stay with them, whose athletic bent walks away with Mr. Foxs commendation and leaves a gauche Ash pale in comparison.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is an incredibly delightful film. It takes sometime for the main plot to begin to pick up steam. However Anderson does a wonderful job of introducing you to the world and his characters that make you feel like their is history and genuine relationships between them. However, the issue with this, is that the beginning of the film brings much more comedy and the latter half of the film is much more serious, and not as interesting. While the latter half is still great, it drags on a bit more after multiple viewings. This is only because Anderson has established his world so much. It almost makes you want to forego the plot just so you can sit and enjoy his world, without changes made to it, just a bit longer. Almost everything about this film clicks so well even mixing of the audiences, whether you viewed it as an adult or a child, was done almost flawlessly. The themes represented, including: self acceptance, ego management, and mid life crisis, means that people of all ages can find a reason to love and attach themselves to this film.  If you haven't seen it yet. Do yourself a favor and go see it now.
Sweet, clever, witty, visually stunning. Everything you can usually expect from a Wes Anderson film.

While raiding Berk's Squab Farm, Mr. Fox and his wife Felicity trigger a fox trap and become caged. Felicity reveals to Fox that she is pregnant and pleads with him to find a safer job when they escape.

Two years later (twelve in Fox Years), the Foxes and their sullen son Ash are living in a hole. Fox, now a newspaper columnist, moves the family into a better home in the base of a tree, ignoring the warnings of his lawyer Badger about how dangerous the area is for foxes. The tree is located very close to facilities run by three mean farmers consisting of Walter Boggis, Nathaniel Bunce, and Franklin Bean. Soon after the Foxes move in, Felicity's nephew Kristofferson Silverfox comes to live with them as his father has become very ill with double pneumonia. Ash finds this situation intolerable; his soft-spoken cousin is apparently superior to him at almost everything, and everyone, including his father, Mr. Fox, is charmed by Kristofferson at Ash's expense.

Fox and Kylie Opossum steal produce and poultry from the three farms. The farmers decide to kill Fox and camp out near the family's tree. When Fox emerges, the farmers open fire, but manage only to shoot off his tail. They then attempt to dig Fox out. After demolishing the site of the tree, the farmers discover the Foxes have dug an escape tunnel.

Reasoning that the Foxes will have to surface for food and water, the farmers lie in wait at the tunnel mouth. Underground, Fox encounters Badger and many other local animal residents whose homes have also been destroyed. As the animals begin fearing starvation, Fox leads Clive Badger, Mole, Beaver, and Weasel in a digging expedition to tunnel to the three farms, robbing them clean. While the other animals feast, Ash and Kristofferson, beginning to reconcile after Kristofferson defended Ash from Mr. Beaver's son, return to Bean's farm, intending to reclaim Mr. Fox's tail. When they are interrupted by the arrival of Bean's wife, Ash escapes but Kristofferson is captured.

Discovering that Fox has stolen their produce, the farmers flood the animals' tunnel network with cider. The animals are forced into the sewers and Fox learns that the farmers plan to use Kristofferson to lure him into an ambush. The animals are confronted by Rat, Bean's security guard. Fox and Rat fight in an electrical room until Fox pushes him into an electric generator, severely electrocuting him. Rat confesses Kristofferson's location before his death.

Fox asks the farmers for a meeting in town near the sewer hub where he would surrender in exchange for Kristofferson's freedom. The farmers set up an ambush, but Fox and the others anticipate it and launch a counterattack. Fox, Ash and Kylie slip into Bean's farm. A much-matured Ash frees Kristofferson and braves enemy fire to release a rabid beagle named Spitz to keep the farmers at bay.

The animals become accustomed to living in the sewers with others considering moving in. Ash and Kristofferson settle their differences and become good friends. Fox leads his family to a drain opening built into the floor of a supermarket owned by the three farmers. Celebrating their new food source and the news that Felicity is pregnant again, the animals dance in their aisles.

There are those who don't like this film, who critise it for not being what Dahl would of wanted. These are the cynics who are completely oblivious to its sheer genius. This film is everything a Dahl film should be. Its deliriously funny, completely incomprehensible and astoundingly crafted. Wes Anderson, I say this to you now, this is not only an achievement in stop motion but an animated masterpiece. And who the hell on God's green earth cant love the fabulous voices of George Clooney and Meryl Streep? The screenplay is tender, charming, witty and first and foremost enjoyably sensational. Not since The Nightmare Before Christmas (excluding claymation) has stop motion been so splendid. It seems, like James and the Giant Peach, Dahl's books are best for stop motion. This is competing against Up for best animated picture at the oscars and I know I gave it the same rating, but this is simply that little bit better and more nuanced. Anyone who says that animation cant live up to the standards of live-action is bloody kidding themselves. And this film prooves that in spades

Review In A Nutshell:

Animation has been, in recent years, a bit predictable and safe. Disney films, with only some as an exception, have taken familiar a formula to drive almost all of their films with only a minor set of tweaks, hoping it would be enough to create a sense of originality. In the hand-drawn animation department, Studio Ghibli is winning the battle with their bold and graceful artistic choices, fuelled by a sense of imagination and hidden symbolism. Pixar has established themselves as the leaders of three-dimensional computer graphic animations to create wonderful stories that deliver multi-generational accessibility and richly appealing characters and worlds. Fantastic Mr. Fox belongs in the underrated category of stop-animation films, which is an area of animated filmmaking that rarely gains a large audience, as some feel it lacks the realism and wonder that other modes of animation could deliver, and the difficult process of creating such a feature does not entirely justify the benefits of the finished product.

I believe that animation should not be limited by its two popular options. There are gems found in a stop-motion animated film that easily becomes lost when told in another medium. If Fantastic Mr. Fox was told through hand-drawn animation then all of its three-dimensional charm is lost, creating flat characters and a world lacking in complexity. Using three-dimensional computer graphics could achieve that extra dimensions that the hand-drawn animations lack, but they tend to give that smooth texture that keeps the film from seeming life-like, also the comedic aspect of the film wouldn't have been achieved as effectively if told in this way. Stop-motion animation may not be the most deliver the smoothest of movement from its characters, but it doesn't have to because what we are seeing are actual living objects that are interacting with one another, which is hard to convey with the other two options.

The film was under the direction of visual director, Wes Anderson, and what he brings to this is a sense of style that is certainly familiar to the fans that have been long following his work, but it also brings something entirely different and unique to the realm of stop-motion animation; the film is leaps and bounds beyond Chicken Little and the Wallace and Gromit films. Anderson's visual and artistic trademarks are here and they are on full display, giving the characters and their world a sense of strangeness and eccentricity, gaining a sense of escape during the experience; but since Anderson is handling fictional characters rather than human projections, their personalities do not seem as odd or intense as his previous films. It actually allows it to become easier for a person, who is unfamiliar with the director, to come into this and still feel like they just experienced another run-of-the-mill animated film; and Anderson knew his target audience and what their expectations were. If he decided to crank up his usual style to maximum, just so the film would really stand out from its peers, then itâ??s going to have people turn their heads and probably lose the natural charm that made the film so appealing.

I cannot note in this review whether the film remained true to Roald Dahl's novel, as I have yet to read it; therefore do not expect any comparisons here, and everything I would state or judge on the film's story would be purely based on the film itself. Wes Anderson returns as the film's screenwriter, collaborating once again with his friend Noah Baumbach to create Fantastic Mr. Fox. I was a little sceptical on whether or not I would find myself pleased with the film, as when they both worked together previously on The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou, I was left disappointed and so far I have regarded it as Anderson's weakest film. After watching this, I was a little stunned on how much I actually enjoyed it. It provided a simple and accessible story, but made it feel mature and complex in its core relationships. They treat the film's characters with effort and respect, demonstrating layers that shape their outer personality and acts as drives to the logic of their decision-making. Dialogue is another thing that the film does wonderfully well, with characters seemingly distinctive and back and forth chatter that is not only hilarious but also thoughtful; it coveys its themes through the intentions and values of its characters, ensuring that the film is about them and not something much larger, like what was done in The Darjeeling Limited. The film also manages to be risky in its choice of words, bringing up themes that seem inappropriate for a young person to hear but hidden cleverly enough behind their hilarious remarks and witty substitution of particular words. They achieve all of this while also providing, assumingly, a faithful interpretation from the source material. Anderson and Baumbach have delivered a screenplay that is both superficially entertaining and emotionally insightful.

The film starts off as a fox couple who live their lives as bandits, benefiting from the riches of their loot, then suddenly Mrs. Fox announces her pregnancy which forces both of them to turn their life around and become a settled and honest family. From there, years later Mr. Fox decides to get back in the game and do one more grand scheme, but then things get out of hand and their entire community becomes affected by his actions. His journey was fun, wild, and tense; there were sequences in here that I would probably never forget, but the film is not really about the spectacle, it's about the relationships and drives of its characters. Mr. Fox is an individual who is driven by his ego, who basks in the glow of success. His sudden change to a "normal" life was manageable at first, but as time went by, it becomes much more difficult to live such a mundane and tedious life where no one even appreciates the writing contributions he brings to the local newspaper. His personality and high expectations also contributes to the dysfunction between him and his son, which is something Anderson treads on frequently with his films. He expects his son to be naturally talented, similar to himself, and passively shows disappointment when he isn't able to fulfil his expectations. It is relationships like these in the film, that makes these characters feel real and complex, rather than empty vessels who's aim is to push the plot forward; it also gives the film naturally earned emotions that aid in the growth of its characters.

Along with its themes of ego and family dysfunction, the film also touches on the idea of adaptation. The film shows us by the end of the film, the determination of these characters to survive in such a difficult and selfish world. In whatever habitat that these animals are put in, they are able to make the best of it, and slowly in their own way fighting and taking back from humans what is rightfully theirs.

Robert Yeoman sadly does not come back here for Fantastic Mr. Fox, and that is understandable as it would take a person who has deep experience of stop-motion animation, and who better than Tristan Oliver, who has previously worked on films including Chicken Run and Wallace and Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit. He is able to do this while still staying close to the vision of the director, emphasising the centred shots and the sudden push-ins and pull-outs. I also cherished the film's orange-brown warm glow to its image, giving it that earth-like feel to it. It was also disappointing to find that Mark Mothersbaugh did not come back to compose the score for Fantastic Mr. Fox, and instead done so by Alexandre Desplat. Desplat is an amazing composer, and his so-far three films with Anderson have been fantastic but there is just something about a long-time collaboration that makes it seem more connected and fantastic. Mothersbaugh brought a lot of charm to Anderson's films, and because of him a lot of his early films sound and feel beautiful. Desplat has a different approach, it has this magical, larger than life quality to his scores, and Fantastic Mr. Fox is one of his more grounded and child-like works, which suited to the film's story and characters. I don't know why I even decided to make a comparison if Desplat did an equally strong enough job in this film. I think I just cannot help but wonder on what the film would have sounded like if it Mothersbaugh was under the role instead.

The film's cast was fantastic, as expected, with new members joining Anderson's troupe; George Clooney and Meryl Streep. Both were perfect choices of casting, demonstrating effective and heavy chemistry between the two, allowing the emotional scenes of the film feel natural. The rest of the cast are familiar members of Anderson's filmography; Bill Murray, Owen Wilson, Jason Schwartzman, Willem Dafoe, Michael Gambon, Adrien Brody and Brian Cox. All of them do a wonderful job with their characters, especially Jason Schwartzman.

Fantastic Mr. Fox feels like a refinement of Steve Zissou, executing character-driven stories with large and ambitious action sequences; laying the groundwork for his audience of the direction of his future as a filmmaker.

There's a lot to be said about a Wes Anderson film; the composition is nearly, always perfect, the characters written are admirably, adorably quirky. The cast is unusually well balanced and the story always goes in a direction you never expect it to go. The same can be said about the absolutely brilliant and wonderful Fantastic Mr. Fox, which douses the viewer in autumn hues and takes them on an inspiring journey of imaginative visuals and story telling, teaching the importance of family and friends nd their commitment of what another (as well as reaching out to the wild animal inside each and every one of us). Based on the story by Roald Dahl, this film is just as entertaining for children as it is for adults and the animation is a wonder to watch. Everyone should take time out of their busy schedule at some point to sit down and watch this film with friend, family, someone you hold dear in your heart. You won't be disappointed!

Mr. Fox was the most successful chicken thief ever. After a close brush with death alongside his wife, he vowed to never put himself or his family in danger again by refraining from stealing anymore chickens. 12 fox years later, with a child in school and his somewhat successful column in the daily newspaper, Mr. Fox feels unsatisfied with his state of life. He decides to go back on his vow to his wife by performing three last chicken heists against the most dangerous chicken farmers in the land. The jobs, though successful, cause the farmers to be vindictive and attempt to destroy everything Mr. Fox loves. Now with his dishonesty in the open, he not only finds himself and his family endangered but the entire animal community as well unless he can change who he is and use his cunning wit in defense of others instead of his own personal gain.
Clever, witty, and pretty humorous. Though the animation and comedy may not appeal to some, the messages that I thought were present should ring a bell with many families. Responsibility and family over personal desires, accepting yourself if you're in the shadow of someone "greater", treating family with love and respect, revenge being more hurtful than good, etc etc. George Clooney was fantastic (pun) in this role. Character traits are well developed and the script was really well written. The humor was frequent, but not over bearing. The best part was seeing how Mr. Fox can change without giving up his traits that truly makes him "fantastic". Awesome movie. I would watch it again multiple times.
Though odd at times,Fantastic Mr.Fox is a good book adaptation to the best selling novel thanks to its cast,funny humor,and impressive story and visual animation.
One of Dahl's best stories is given a nostalgic treatment by Anderson in this loving, but misguided and occasionally boring picture. It's an exercise in style with all of its substance removed.
Funny, twisted, fun, and lots of interesting eye candy, Fantastic Mr. Fox is fantastic!

I love seeing what Wes Anderson can go with what's given to him. 
I'm not sure if anyone really expected much from this movie based off of the Roald Dahl book, mainly since the quality of Dahl's movie adaptations has... varied over the years. And honestly the trailer just didn't really impress me the first time I saw it. 
But like most of Anderson's trailers, the final product ended up being much different from the trailer, this one being for the better. 
The script is very fast paced and fun, giving each character room to say something important or funny. The humor was also great for adults and kids to understand. I also really enjoyed how during the climax quite literally everything began falling apart. It helps show just how drastic things were getting. 
The character of Mr. Fox is kind of a mixed bag. You will either love or hate his mischievous ways. Some of his running gags last a bit too long but I personally liked him. He's charming without overdoing it. He (for the most part) realizes when he's made a mistake and tries to fix it or do what he can with what he's got. The side characters are very fun and quirky from the goofy Kristofferson (great name by the way) to the evil farmers, who also get a couple of good laughs ("You wrote a bad song, Petey! ") By the way, props to Desplat for another great soundtrack. 
The animation, although tough to get used to at first, looked great and unique. This is a film that, like most of Anderson's works, sets itself apart from others. It's animation, characters, camera work, and script all make this movie one of a kind. Whether or not it's unique in a good way is up to you, but personally this was a tasty treat that was wonderful to watch.

Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009) - 7,5

Wes Anderson makes an incursion in Stop motion animation with another comedy. In this fantasy, we watch an amusing open war between 3 wealthy human farmers and alpha male Mr. Fox. After stealing poultry from 3 farms to satisfy his wild beast whims, Mr. Fox and his family have to dig for their lives when faced with the farmers' vengeful fury. Fortunately, this fantasy determines that the personified animals are as smart as people and in the end sly fauna takes the upper hand over Men. "Fantastic Mr. Fox" is worth for the great visual beauty, for the rich characters and the very entertaining humor. Wes Anderson's steady hand in the direction and playful pathos prevents this movie from falling into mediocre territory. I would like to see substantially more facial expression from the animal characters, there were moments of emotional or otherwise persuasive agenda that didn't quite grip me as they could. Technical limitations, I suppose. Small distraction in such a colorful and lively movie. But then again, Wes' characters are never garish in their facial expressions. I was very curious to see how the director would forge his animated subjects and, unremarkably, they are not too different from live-action counterparts. Fun and beautiful animation movie, recommended.

"THREE FARMERS HUNTING DOWN A FOX"  

- Based on the novel of Roald Dahl (Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Mathilda) is this 2009 stop-motion animation film 'Fantastic Mr. Fox' directed by Wes Anderson (The Royal Tenenbaums, The Grand Budapest Hotel). The story is about the war between a fox and three farmers who got robbed of their animals. The film has a retro stylish look and is very suitable to watch with the kids. With the voices of George Clooney (From Dusk till Dawn, Ocean's Eleven), Meryl Streep (The Hours, Death Becomes Her), Jason Schwartzman (Scott Pilgrim vs. the World, The Grand Budapest Hotel), Bill Murray (Lost in Translation, Ghostbusters), Owen Wilson (Meet the Parents, Zoolander), Willam Dafoe (Spiderman, Antichrist), Brian Cox (X-men 2, Troy) and Adrien Brody (King Kong, Predators). 

Two years (12 fox years) after Mr. Fox (Clooney) and his wife Felicity (Streep) have given up their job of raiding farms, they live a normal boring life in a hole in the ground with their son Ash (Schwatzman). One day Mr. Fox decides to move to a luxurious tree, situated on a hill overseeing three farms. Every night he sneaks out of his home to raid one of the farms with the help of opossum Kyle. But it doesn't take long before the fat chicken farmer Walter Boggis, the little goose farmer Nathaniel Bunce and the tall turkey farmer Franklin Bean join forces to hunt down the thieves. Unwillingly Mr. Fox has endangered not only himself, but also his family and neighbors...
Smart, Funny and Original... Fantastic Mr. Fox adds another success to stop motion animation.

This animated outing by Wes Anderson is without a doubt one of the best animated films i have seen in a very, very long time. It's full of life, fun, intricacies that just blow your mind. Whats even more amazing is that even though this is an animated outing, you genuinly feel like your there, with the cinematography being constantly on the move, follwing the insane plots/manuevers that Mr Fox gets us into, its a work of genius. Mr and Mrs Fox, played by Clooney and Streep (Wonderfully i might add), spend their time hunting down chickens from farms and doing what foxes do. One day while on the steal, Mrs Fox confesses to Mr Fox she is pregnant and that this way of life must stop. Flash forward 12 years later, they have a kid called Ash, Mr Fox is a coloumist and everything seems hunky dory. However discontent with his lack of wealth and letting his nature take over, Mr fox decides to hatch a plan to raid three different farms, the results, not only destroy the animal community but also put Mr Foxes life and family at risk. The animation is so fresh to see in this day and age, this is a dying form and its so good to see it being put to good use here. The voice acting is astounding and hilarious, for the first time in an age Clooney gives a performance we were so used to from yesteryear. The usual people show up in smaller roles, trade mark Murray, but its absolutley fine and none jarring due to the animated nature. Willem DaFoe's rat however is just the pinncacle of hillarity at one point during the film, i wont spoil. I genuinley dont have a single bad word to say against this movie apart from its seems about 5 minutes to long, that however is barely a gripe. Excellent piece of cinema and animation, forget your toy stories and your Up!'s this, my friends, is where the magic is at.

I think you either 'get' Wes Anderson movies or you don't. By 'get', I mean a connection. It's maybe the unique way they are shot. Often square to the subject occasionally moving in a single direction. Or it's the detail crammed into every scene. It could be the no-nonsense dialog and the impeccable comic timing, or all the above. What ever it is - you 'get' it, and love Wes Anderson films. Or you don't, and you can't stand them. It's not a measure of intelligence. You either do or you don't. Happily for me, I 'get' his movies. They click, and that makes me happy! :-)

The Fantastic Mr. Fox is no exception. The stop-motion animation is superb, and really suits Wes Anderson's story telling style. The whole production is so bloody charming! Mr. Fox can't seem to control his basic animal instincts, and repeatedly (despite Mrs Fox's objections) snatches livestock from three neighboring farms. This then leads to a retaliatory strike by the farmers. Retaliation leads to escalation as the Fox family and their many friends escape the farmers and try to help themselves to everything the farmers have!

It all moves along at a great pace, and the script is sharp, surprising and always funny. I do however think this is going to appeal to big kids more.

Movie Prep:

If you remember the book by Roald Dahl, be warned the movie adds to the story. If you 'get' Wes Anderson's work then you're likely going to enjoy this too. The darker tone and humor in this story may not appeal to younger kids.

Best Format:

It is a visual treat, so a HD showing at home with the family could be fun.

Best element for me:

I loved the scenes with Mr. Fox's son, Ash (Jason Schwartzman.) A great character, trying to find his way out from under his fantastic father's shadow. He just gets the funniest dialog.

Ash: You're supposed to be *my* lab partner.

Agnes: I am!

Ash: No you're not. You're disloyal.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is an impressive, and very different animated film, brought to us by the clever and bizarre Wes Anderson. The movie is a fully realized adaptation of Roald Dahl's book of the same name.

The story follows Mr. Fox who lives with his wife, and his young pup Ash. As soon as Mr. Fox learned he would be having a kid, he decided to get out of the chicken stealing business for good. Although, he missed it, he took up work as a columnist for the local newspaper. One day, Mr. Fox announces how displeased he is with being poor, denouncing the absurd idea of living in a 'fox hole'. Soon, Fox and his buddies team up to rob the three big farms in town of all their chicken and alcoholic apple cider. The schemes are smart and sly, but draw enough attention to initiate all out war between the animals and the farmers.

This is easily one of the more interesting animated movies I've seen. First off, the story is nothing ground breaking. It's a funny one, but nothing that's completely outside the box. That being said, it's still a good story. The one thing you first notice with Fantastic Mr. Fox, is it's awesome animation style. There are a lot of beautifully 3D rendered animations coming out all the time, but it's once in a blue moon a filmmaker comes out and injects something new into the same old song and dance. Not only that, but Wes Anderson gives the film a great balance of humor that caters to both children and adults. All great voice overs from Clooney, Streep, Bill Fucking Murray, and Schwartzman.

Along with his familiar cast, Wes Anderson did not forget to bring in his style when creating this one. It's a Wes Anderson through and through, and by now his style has helped create a name for himself. It's abstract, weird, awkward, and clever, with razor sharp banter like dialogue. The writing is one of the stand out key elements beyond the great animation and art direction. I love the style of this movie though. It's like Wes Anderson didn't decide to just make a movie about Roald Dahl's book, but made it his own. He put the Anderson stamp on it, and it feels like every one of his other movies, which is awesome. It's like if Scorcese one day decided to create a cartoon film about the mafia crime scene. It might be a toned down cartoon, but you know who made it even if the form of film is not traditional to the filmmaker.

Although, the movie is great in many aspects, I didn't feel the heartwarming vibe it tried going for. There's a moral to this story, but it's somewhat squandered beyond the constant dry joking character interaction. It's subtle and deadpan humor, that kind of fails to insert that loving, moral bit. The movie could go on even longer than it did, although that could possibly ruin it too. It's a short, fun, cartoon, that could make anyone smile. That's the one thing that makes this one fresh.

Peeked into the foxhole and found myself a little hidden gem here. There are a fair share of silly jokes which is right up my alley while even some of the not-so-hilarious content seems funnier due to the well executed quick paced dialogue from the voice actors. The story itself moves at the same quick speed as well which works great since there is practically no useless filler material, making it very hard for anyone to lose interest. They often use different camera angles for the escape/rescue scenes which adds another dimension to the storytelling while also invoking a few more laughs. Much like Pingu (anyone remember that?) or Robot Chicken (anyone heard of that?), 'Fantastic Mr Fox' uses stop-motion animation. This distinguishes it from what has become your bog standard cartoon animations of late, allowing it to implement its own unique styles of visual humour.

A wonderful animated feature that captures the idiosyncrasies found in wild animals to create a rather ironic and thoughtful narrative. The existentialist crises that haunt these animals seem to touch on our human, albeit mammalian, lives as well. It is ironic that the viewer will find him/herself connecting more with the animals than the human counterparts. To the mechanical side of things, the script moves at a dutifully brisk pace with nary a dull moment and the voice acting is simply superb. This is one feature that can appeal to the entire spectrum of viewers, either aging or incredibly young: a feat that is seldom achieved in an animated feature. Wes Anderson's vision was ahem, spot on!

There is this awkward crooked quirky sense of humour to the film that is simply fantastic.
Always loved Roald Dahl and his sense of humour. 
And George Clooney and Meryl Streep sound amazingly foxy.
one of my favorites!!

This is definitely a good film. Visually it is rather interesting and quite engaging in a way, which is rather refreshing for animated features. The musical score was definitely the high point of the film! Simply brilliant. However, never having read the book, the film itself does not seem to have a point to it. If one watches it and disregards that it's a children's book originally, one would ask themselves "what the heck is the point of this thing???" despite it being rather entertaining. Also, the actors did an excellent job with the voice-over, especially George Clooney, and it was lovely to hear Meryl Streep's voice!

Overall, it is definitely a good film, but keep in mind that it does not necessarily have a point to it. It's a children's story turned into a film. Fun, but not very deep/challenging
This movie made me laugh so hard!

Wes Anderson may not just be one of the best directors who I think needs to direct a blockbuster, but you could even make the argument that there is a huge resemblance to what this movie, Fantastic Mr. Fox means to me. To see other directors start to employ animation to create stories whose maturity and clever humor blur the line between adult audiences and children's audiences is drastically needed.  I think Wes Anderson may be the guy to make that connection.  This sh---cuss is brilliance.

Amazing visuals with terrific voice acting make for one of the strangest and most unique animated films ever made. being a big George Clooney fan, this film was just the best, and Wes Anderson being another fantastic director.

Even though this is a mildly-hard PG movie, you should not rob your kids of this film. If you enjoyed Chicken Run and Wallace & Gromit: Curse of the Were-Rabbit (though Fox is not as good as these), you will enjoy this, as it is the best claymation movie in a long time.

intellectual comedy with the most perfect eccentricity of Wes Anderson

A delightful, brilliantly animated heist caper that is amusing and entertaining on every level.  From the pitch perfect voice work, the brilliant and classy stop-motion animation, the bizarre and snappy humor, the zany plot, the lovable characters; Fantastic Mr. Fox is a gem of a animated film.  I have so much respect for directors who think outside the box like Wes Anderson.  What could have been a simple cash-in is a memorable tale with so much care taken to create a stop-motion film, and that is commendable enough.  A film I dearly enjoy and would watch again and again!
Absolutely Hilarious
OMG loved this movie so much one of my most favorite movie of all time i loved the characters and the awesome storyline 5 out of 5 stars truly amazing.

This is a treat to the eyes and mind. Anderson delivers his standard style to this film and it pays off ten fold. It is clever, cute, and a tad tripy. It has such a mellow sense of humor and a very good direction about it you can't help but too giggle!

I'm a sucker for awesome dialogue and animation. Especially, this rare animation and Anderson is a unique and extravagant director/writer. I honestly was also struck by the "waterfall" scene, it made me so happy to see something different and amazing.

Definitely one of the most innovative animation films I've ever seen in terms of how it was filmed. I was partially swept away by the typical Wes Anderson charm, and impressed with the occasional dark turns the film would take.

"Fantastic Mr. Fox" is a fantastic (sorry, had to do it) art-house animated movie that's firing on all cylinders; it's got a great ensemble and an atypical screenplay coupled with eye-popping visual flair -- just don't expect this to be a wild ride as you would imagine a wild ride to be. The VISUALS are wild and eccentric, and there may be quirky moments within the plot, but "Fantastic Mr. Fox" keeps its composure throughout.

An incredibly unique film, with an all-star cast, brilliant design, and lots of appeal. Funny, interesting, and nothing like anything you've ever seen, Fantastic Mr. Fox should be a guide for making animated films.

I have always sticked with Wes Anderson even when his movies did not succeed. His last few films have been duds, but Fantastic Mr. Fox is nothing but a hit. The stop motion animation is excellent and sets the quirky tone for the rest of the film. Anderson and his screenwriter Noah Baumbauch throw in inside jokes and adult humor without being self-indulgent or crude. Great use of music throughout plus plenty of great voice acting especially by Schwartzman and Wes Anderson's own brother Eric. A visually successful film that is creatively and meticulously designed. A true triumph of animated filmmaking and Anderson becomes one of the few live action filmmakers to be successful in animation arts.

Astonishingly tedious.  For a while we wondered if it were intended to deliberately be tedious, as some sort of parody - but no, it seems as if the idea really was to use stiffly animated animals to imitate what stiff, boring people do.

It might be that the last hour was better - we couldn't make it through past the first one.  Not one laugh in the whole thing...
Leave it to Wes Anderson to be better than most at displaying what grand ideas a children's tale can behold.

The Roald Dahl classic tale of a sly fox battling a group of angry farmers tired of sharing their chickens with him comes to life in this sublime stop motion animation venture of director Wes Anderson that has a visual depth that most modern animation films lack, with its unique style that represents a true auteur's vision. And while the talking animals and the animation may hide the thematic depth, this film is no less compelling than the other works by the renowned filmmaker but rather more universal and able to capture wider audiences.

Nothing negative to say here.  I was smiling ear to ear throughout.  Except for the oft instances that Anderson always squeezes in when the character discovers something powerfully emotional about his/her existence.  Fuck, I loved this movie.  One of the year's best.  Unless, you hate Wes Anderson, which I know some of you do.  Even so, it's one of his most accessible and enjoyable.  Apparently, a lot of people have been complaining about the Americanization of Dahl's book.  I read the book as a kid, but not with a British accent.  I can see how some might be pissed, but this aspect really did not bother me.  It's an adaptation, not an audio book.

It's too weird, strange, off-beat, and not to forget dull for me to like when Up, Wallace & Gromit, and even Caroline are waaaaaayyyyy better cartoon movies than this one. I might go as far as saying even Cars 2 was better

Loved the use of the word "cuss" in place of any and all curse words; makes the film family friendly without turning into a droll kids flick. Will surely be adding to my collection.
