The Fantastic Mr. Fox seems like a children's movie, but there's so much more to it beneath the surface (pun intended). Not only does Anderson capture the feel of Dahl's story, but he manages to capture his own signature style in a completely new medium without making it overwhelmingly so. The script captures the whimsy of both Dahl and Anderson, the dialogue is witty and snappy, and the characters are well-rounded and well-formed. The movie itself  is visually striking, and it presents one of the more significant achievements in animation in the past decade - a nice contrast to all of the CGI movies being released. In short, this movie is cussing hilarious, and I love the cuss out of it.

Well it's no Charlie and Chocolate Factory or Matilda but it's still decent. I'd say it's closer in feel to James and the Giant Peach. It was a pleasant enough movie with interesting animation but the storyline wasn't all that appealing to me. Also, the majority of the humor was a little dry for my taste but it was still quirky fun.

Wes Anderson is without a doubt the weirdest director ever. Fantastic Mr. Fox, like Moonrise Kingdom, is a whimsical and sweet movie about being true to yourself. He had a lot to say about the world we live in now; what it is that drives us. Continually digging holes could not be more spot on. George Clooney had the easiest job of his career by just putting on a quirky voice and reading lines. There's a lot to be had here. The stop-motion adds to Anderson's style. I don't think this movie is for everyone, but it was entertaining and very thought provoking, especially for an animated movie. Very funny, and very sweet.
fox,badgers,beavers and off course humans  ensemble for a wholesome entertainer from wes craven.comical and surreal mr.fox is brilliant.

It was delightfully refreshing.  Like other Wes Anderson films, it was inhabited by quirky interesting charecters full of charm and depth. I was suprised at the expertise of the animation.  It really showed the versatility of the medium. The close up shots of the faces show a great emotional depth.  Possibly the best stop motion animation film since the "Nightmare Before Christmas" maybe even better.

Elevated by quirky animation and a plethora of great character moments, Fantastic Mr Fox is yet further proof that Wes Anderson is one of the most talented and unique directors working in Hollywood today.

Wes Anderson Has Made Yet Another Masterpiece. "Fantastic Mr. Fox" Is Dazzling To Behold. The Film Takes A Simple And Beloved Children's Story And Transforms It Into A Magnificent Work Of Art. The Animation Is Amazing And Wonderfully Quirky. Anderson's Critics Complain That His Aesthetic Does Not Allow For Realism And His Characters Feel Artificial. With An Animated Film, Anderson Can Be As Creative And Audacious As He Needs To Be And Still Provide Emotional Truth While Creating Vibrant And Wonderfully Eccentric Characters. Anderson Co-Wrote The Screenplay With Noah Baumbach, The Writer-Director Of "Greenberg", "Margot At The Wedding", And "The Squid And The Whale". The Voices Include George Clooney, Eric Anderson, Jason Schwartzman, Bill Murray, Meryl Streep, Owen Wilson, And Willem Dafoe. All Of Them Are Brilliant And Absolutely Hysterical. The Film Is One Of The Finest Films I Have Seen In Years. It Ranks Among Anderson's Other Great Works Such As "Rushmore" And "The Royal Tenenbaums" "Fantastic Mr. Fox" Is The Single Greatest Animated Film That I Have Ever Seen. The Film Is Emotionally Resonant And Incredibly Heartwarming. This Film Made Me Feel Alive In A Way That Few Other Films Have. Wes Anderson's "Fantastic Mr. Fox" Is One Of The Very Best Films Of The Decade.
Not as good as Moonrise Kingdom but still a fantastic movie with some great animation and just as wired as all of Wes Anderson's movies.

Lush autumn visuals, typical intricate Wes Anderson visuals with an animated twist, memorable characters and a script packed with witticisms make Fantastic Mr. Fox truly enjoyable fare. Its voice cast with such names as George Clooney, Meryl Streep and Jason Schwartzman add weight to an already lovely mix, with a fox outsmarting a slew of farmers and other humans in this film based on Roald Dahl's children's book.
Bringing its own style of quirky stop-motion animation to the table, Fantastic Mr. Fox is a well-crafted adaptation of the fabulous Roald Dahl novel.
More a Wes Anderson movie than a conventional children's animated film, and is all the better off for it.  Funny and touching
Fantastic in every way.
best animated film of 2009
Hilarious, tender, and with quirky animation that Wes Anderson pulls off beautifully, Fantastic Mr. Fox can be thoroughly enjoyed by children and adults alike.

Easily the best movie I've seen all year. It's so original and witty, It's easily reached my top ten list of all-time favourites Every time I watch it I see something new that adds to the plot, every detail is so interwoven into the rest of the story, it's impossible not to fall in love! I highly recommend, one of Anderson's best works!
Well, i never read the children's book. So i don't know if the film does it any justice or not. But in it's own right, it's as "fantastic" as one would expect a Wes Anderson movie to be.

As a fan of the book written by Roald Dahl, the story itself is predictable: A family of foxes goes out to nick food from three farmers named Boggis, Bunce and Bean and so do other woodland animals but when the farmers find out, that their food is slowly going missing because of those animals, one of the farmers tries to shoot them down but it's up to the animals to get together to get together and win over the three farmers and get the food they need to stop themselves from starving. Fantastic Mr.Fox the movie adaptation itself is fantastic. I guess I could argue that a lot of scenes that weren't from the book were added to the movie to make the film longer but that's just nitpicking. Overall this movie has it's target audience handled well and the film itself has spot-on animation and unbelievable voice-acting. Fantastic Mr.Fox gets a 9.5/10.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is one of the best animated features of the last decade. It leaves behind the sentimentality of most successful (and "Disney-fied") animated movies, in favor, of an off-beat, adventure story that ultimately still brings about a fulfilling ending. Mr. Fox discovers that he'll always be a wild animal and that this is okay; he does not need to try to be someone else to please his family. As long as he cares about them, he will always be fantastic.

Wes Anderson's take on inspirational writer Roald Dahl's famous children's book Fantastic Mr. Fox may not be fantastic, however you could go far worse as far as animations are concerned. 

Anderson already has our attentions gripped with one glance at the star studded and family style casting. 

George Clooney as the smooth talking Mr Fox was almost meant to be - written in the stars if you will. He is the perfect choice for a family animation as his voice is heart warming and gentle; this is why he should have stayed well away of the Batman role in 1997.

Also cast is comedy legend Bill Murray, Meryl Streep, the veteran Williem Dafoe and Owen Wilson. Each deliver amicable performances which can be deemed acceptable by any standard. A solid back up cast.

If you are unfamiliar with the plot of Fantastic Mr. Fox is basically follows the journey of Mr. Fox and his family as they attempt to avoid the merciless capture of three farmers.

There are some nice touches to this film and it has a quirky feel throughout; although as I am familiar with the story it didn't have much else to offer. A decent tale on Dahl's book - a decent animation truth be told - just not a great one.

"Fantastic Mr. Fox" is a great family/stop-motion animated film (nominated for the Oscar for Best Animated Feature; lost to "Up") & stays faithful to the children's book by late author Roald Dahl; if Dahl were alive, I'm quite sure he would love this film.

I'm deciding to give this a more positive review than I'm used to giving films that I didn't enjoy. The problem with this film is that it's good aspects equal it's bad aspects and so it really doesn't feel right with me. There are three categories that I'll talk about, and each one I'll have reasons of why I liked parts and didn't like other parts. The three categories are 

Visuals - I'm not going to lie, I LOVE stop animation films. Nightmare Before Christmas blows my mind with how well animated it is, and I honestly couldn't tell that it was stop motion the first few times through. Fantastic Mr. Fox is clearly stop motion, and sometimes that works to it's advantage, other times no. For example, the style of the action scenes makes it kind of funny, and when characters get electrocuted, it has a stop motion comedic appeal of seeming like it was poorly made. The film also has visual appeal of never really having a boring shot. The cinematography is excellent. However, the problem with the film lies in emotional visualization. It's hard to tell how a character is feeling based off of the expression on their faces. They have flat expressions and their mouth movements also hurt the ability for characters to LOOK how they feel. This will immediately cause problems for some if not most viewers, as it makes it awkward to watch. It's kind of sad that a skeleton from 1993 has better visual emotions than a fox from 2009.

Writing - Writing for me does not include plot development and character progression, but this is limited just to writing dialogue and scenes. The dialogue has it's good moments and bad moments too. It falls into a comedic trap that makes the film not very funny. This trap is actually a formula for jokes in the film. Here's the formula -

Somebody does/says something, usually illogical
Somebody else questions the logic of the previous person
The first person tries to defend/explain themselves, etc.

Basically, I could have written every joke in this movie just by watching one scene, because that's how it feels. I think Wes Anderson believes that comedic situations in films like this can only come from a self-awareness, and that's a major problem with this film, everything feels too self aware. If you watch (and this is an odd comparison) an episode of Spongebob Squarepants,SPECIFICALLY earlier episodes, you'll notice that it hardly ever breaks self-awareness, and when it does, it's usually a character like Squidward or Plankton and nobody else questions it. An example - the episode where Squidward throws Spongebob back into the kitchen, and then all of a sudden Spongebob is back with him saying "this is serious!"... Squidward is shocked that Spongebob was able to get there so fast, but nobody else notices. It's funnier this way when nobody is actually aware that they're actors in a crazy cartoon. 

Fantastic Mr. Fox, however, does it all wrong in that sense, by having the characters constantly question logic decisions of other people (of which the decisions might even be movie cliches, thus giving Fantastic Mr. Fox a sense of "meta"). We know the universe is illogical, we don't need you to constantly be a voice of reason. Comedies are funnier when there is NO voice of reason, and the only potential voices of reason are treated as unimportant or even crazy, or just ignored altogether.

A positive of the writing, however, is that things happen quick often, requiring people to pay attention. What I'm saying is that it got it's pacing right, but it's jokes usually fall flat. 

Plot and style - The film's visual style is ok, but it's choice of music is all wrong. The film feels like it has way too much nostalgia for the 70's. Of course, this is to feed the machine of hipsters and older viewers who care for that kind of thing, but it's unnecessary. I mean, yes, it's an adaptation of a 70's book, but if I want a Dahl adaptation with a 70's feel, I'll go watch Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, which was MADE in the 70's. I'm not saying that I want it to be full of people texting or whatever, but there's such a thing as timeless appeal, and if you're going to make a timeless movie you have to not date it so. Willy Wonka, despite all of it's 70's dated looks of characters, still kind of exists in it's own world. The factory is timeless because no matter what era you're from, it's still an odd factory, and the parts outside of the factory definitely don't give off a strictly 70's vibe. The film still feels fresh because it never openly said "this is the 70's", whereas the REMAKE happened to feel dated for much the opposite reason, making it TOO obvious what time period it was supposed to be, and also having CGI, which usually makes something look dated.

Basically, what I'm saying with Fantastic Mr. Fox is that it lacks the clear timelessness of many other "family films", simply because it tries to feed the indie audience by giving it a strictly 70's vibe, which alienates viewers who AREN'T fans of The Beach Boys or The Rolling Stones (keep in mind, I know that the songs used are pre-70's, but they would have been played on the radio during the 70's anyways). The film's style just lacks an inclusive feel. It's exclusive to the hipster/indie fanbase and it kind of makes it hard for me to watch.

The plot progression I actually thought was decent. The beginning portion of the film was "meh", and the end was "meh", but the middle portion was good. Of course, Roald Dahl's book is just the middle portion of the film, but I'll give credit to the film-makers for doing a good job adapting the book in that sense, giving it a proper pacing and so on.

The characters are sometimes bland and other times decent. Mr. Fox is not the most interesting protagonist, and I honestly don't understand why they follow him, although they show that he's definitely the best fit to be a leader, so it's excused that he seems somewhat dumb (his plan that he develops to grab all of the farmer's supplies while they have all of their men out of the factories was something I came up with long before Mr. Fox came up with it). His wife is also bland, a boring "you shouldn't do it" character. His son is kind of bland too. His nephew was interesting to me, albeit a character I've seen plenty of before (the character being the person who has done nothing wrong but still creates a strong amount of jealousy in another character). The possum was a good character as was Franklin Bean. The rest I was indifferent to.


Now, after all of that, why am I giving it a 70%? I seemed to not like it that much. Well what I'm saying is that I haven't quite seen a film like it, although elements of it are just treading the same water that I usually hate. I can't stand the indie film scene, because a large amount of it is warm-hearted manufactured BS that gets away with praise because of being indie and stylistic. I've seen too many happy ending stories and throwing in quirkiness like indie films do doesn't somehow make it better that I'm being manipulated. I prefer films with realism to their craft, such as Kubrick's films where it's not necessarily winners or losers, and it's not necessarily the ones we want to win who do. I'm not against happy endings, but it has to have a sense of realism to it. A great example of a happy ending that works is This is Spinal Tap, where it's not necessarily the infallibility of the characters or the lesson learned or the ridiculous luck of survival that leads to a happy ending, but instead an agent of circumstance. I prefer happy endings to not force their way into a plot, but instead ease their way into a plot by having the characters ACTUALLY develop. The sense of realism has to start from the beginning and work it's way to the end.

I know it's odd to talk about realism with an animated film, so I'll shorten my review to this - the film has it's problems, and is generally another "indie" film that falls into indie cliches in order to make the film seem unique and quirky. I don't like that, but I appreciate the efforts of the people involved and I wasn't mad watching it, I just happened to not laugh. It's not a very funny movie, although it can be somewhat funny at times, but I recommend it as a great visual piece with elements of actual GOOD film-making mixed in between the expected indie quirks and sub-Pixar animated phoniness of character development.

I wondered, "How on earth is George Clooney gonna be a convincing voice actor?" Well, Fantastic Mistuh Fox is surprisingly matched with a dexterous screenplay, almost as if it were catered to the adult crowd -- in other words, George Clooney was a perfectly well-casted gentleman. Funny thing is that although its fixated to please adults, the style is so artistically over-the-top, wild, and comical that this adventure is a lot of fun for the kids as well. 

Now, by how "Fantastic Mr. Fox" has been described so far, it should seem like the narrative would be executed in a sort of clustered but calculated way, right? Nope, Wes Anderson rightfully keeps it clean and linear: it's the perfect balance of whimsical dialogue and themes, and the eccentric personality. Luckily, this linearity's coupled with good-hearted themes and a soft heart. And what a tribute to Roald Dahl's book; rendered to an almost complete picture-book-esque style, the cinematography is absolutely beautiful. The composition, the stop-motion technology, and the colors really pop out of the screen. The style is so overbearingly superb, the narrative just doesn't reach the same caliber throughout. Yes, the pacing is even and the voice-acting is all around great, but the entertainment value of the entire picture doesn't quite manage to deliver the same affection as its style. No need to worry-- it's not overbearingly fixated on art-house visuals that they complete alienate the children. "Fantastic Mr. Fox" is still a lot of fun, but compared to many animated movies out there, it's on the short end of the stick.

"Fantastic Mr. Fox" is a fantastic (sorry, had to do it) art-house animated movie that's firing on all cylinders; it's got a great ensemble and an atypical screenplay coupled with eye-popping visual flair -- just don't expect this to be a wild ride as you would imagine a wild ride to be. The VISUALS are wild and eccentric, and there may be quirky moments within the plot, but "Fantastic Mr. Fox" keeps its composure throughout.

Mr and Mrs Fox live an idyllic home life with their son Ash and visiting young nephew Kristofferson. But after 12 years, the bucolic existence proves too much for Mr Fox's wild animal instincts. Soon he slips back into his old ways as a sneaky chicken thief and in doing so, endangers not only his beloved family, but the whole animal community. Trapped underground and with not enough food to go around, the animals band together to fight against the evil Farmers - Boggis, Bunce and Bean - who are determined to capture the audacious, fantastic Mr Fox at any cost.

There have been many of Roald Dahl's books brought to the movie world. We've had movies such as James and the Giant Peach, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, The Witches, The BFG and now Fantastic Mr. Fox, which has proven to be quite the diamond. The story is brilliant which is to be expected since it's based on a Roald Dahl book, the animation is bright and colourful and is simply superb as it uses the original classic stop motion animation. The voice acting has no faults and the characters were beautifully written and a lot of fun to watch. It's guaranteed to leave you grinning from ear to ear after you finish watching it.

When I first saw the trailer for this movie, I must admit I did have some doubts but after putting them aside and watching the movie, I could see I had nothing to worry about as this is truly a classic animation for children and adults to watch. The humour involved in the movie is great and timed perfectly. It surprised me as well because, and I don't know if this is me but, the animation looked choppy and kind of slow yet when watching the animation, it was nice and smooth and ran perfectly. Almost everything about Fantastic Mr. Fox was near enough perfect to how a family animation should be. However, nothing is ever perfect and I doubt I'll ever see a perfect movie. Having said that, this movie comes pretty close to being the perfect family movie. I really do recommend this movie to everyone as I have yet to find a person who didn't fall for the charm of Fantastic Mr. Fox. This will definitely keep the whole family entertained and adults and children will adore it. I thank the cast and the crew for bringing such a classic story to life and making it fantastic.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is an admittedly almost overly quirky but still smart, witty, wonderfully animated and beautifully shot stop-motion, seemingly more adult appealing, but still also kids film, with a unique, intelligent script, solid direction from Wes Anderson, perfect voice work, and rarely has a dull or unexciting shot in it.

Perhaps not the most well known of Roald Dahl's books, Fantastic Mr.Fox lacks some of his dark imagination but this version is well made enough to raise a few smiles and packs a generous helping of witticisms into it's script to ensure that neither kids or adults will get bored.
The premise involves the eponymous Mr. Fox having something akin to a feral life crisis as he tries to recapture his old life as a chicken rustler by stealing from three rather nasty farmers and bringing a whole heap of trouble for him and his animal friends, much to the dismay of his family.
The characterisations in the film are good.  George Clooney voices a likeable Mr Fox but as with most Roald Dahl tales, it's the evil doers who are the most fun.  The three farmers are the most memorable and interesting characters in the movie, as well as their henchmen, Willam Dafoe, in fine voice as an effeminate ninja rat.
The films script is amusing and guaranteed to raise a smile, even if the joke of inserting the word 'cuss' every time a character swears does grow old after the first half of the film.
The animation style will not be to everyones tastes.  It does take some getting used to.  There are times when you feel like you've almost got to squint at it to see what is happening which gets a little distracting.  It's a bold move to use this stop motion animation style rather than a straight forward cgi/Pixar style but it's a bit much for a whole hour and a half.
Fantastic Mr.Fox is an amicable enough movie.  It's not likely to be supplanting Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory atop anyone's favourite Roald Dahl films but it's a nice, empty half term afternoon killer.

Thought it would be too "adult" for the kids but they enjoyed it so much in their own way.  I, on the other hand, was intrigued by Clooney and Streep's calming voices amidst such chaos, music of the 60s and the unexpectedly amazing animation (if this can even be called animation).  Just excellent.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is absolutely a marvelous film. I've always been quite fond of Wes Anderson and this film just oozes with his style while still managing to successfully bring a beloved children's tale to vivid and colorful life. This is also, far and away, one of his funniest films. Some might argue that Rushmore holds that title, but I disagree. It's chock full of great character moments and some very funny one-liners, all while managing to keep a grip on the story mechanics and the actual reality of it all. My only complaint, as if there could be any, is that it all goes by so fast and feels too short. Nonetheless, it's enjoyable, and should please most people wanting to have a fairly simple story told to them with great characters and dialogue, not to mention some of the finest stop-motion animation of recent memory. I highly recommend it.

Another great film and a superb animated movie from director Wes Anderson. Fantastic Mr. Fox, in my opinion, only rivals the Pixar films in the world of modern animation. I enjoyed this film as much as the children did in the theater, which is a circumstance characteristic of Pixar in general. Then again, I am a Wes Anderson fan, so I have some bias. Not everyone admires Anderson's style in his films, and his style does translate directly into Fantastic Mr. Fox. The combination of this style of animation, Wes Anderson's filmmaking, a solid voice cast, and a children's story makes Fantastic Mr. Fox into one refreshing whole. Its nice to see a film (or animated film for that matter) have a level of creativity that surpasses most films in release today. 

Here's an interesting suggestion: what if Anderson collaborated with Pixar on a film? What would be the result? Chances are the movie watching population will never find out, but it poses some thought on the possible results of an unusual collaboration in Hollywood today.

Seriously though, this is prolly his best one yet. It has all of his signature elements:  a surreal world with quirky, weird characters that hatch elaborate schemes for success. And as for the depressing moments, yes, they are still there, but they act more like undertones, to keep the story flowing smoothly. The voice acting was easily recognizable (Clooney and Streep as the leads), and most of the WA crew make an appearance (Owen Wilson, Bill Murray, Jason Schwartzman), which is a plus. It feels much more like a Wes Anderson original rather than a Ronald Dahl adaptation. It took me a whopping 10-15 minutes to go from hating the worn and dull stop motion animation to loving it, so I guess it grows on you. Oh, and the slang humor was absolutely hilarious: they took your average Wes Anderson film, which usually gets an R rating for some language, and they replaced the swears with the word "cuss", i.e. "You scared the cuss out of us!" Now that may not sound funny here in writing, but trust me, it works. Laughed every time. Plus that helped turn it into a family-friendly film. Here's a movie with a boastful title that truly lives up to its name! Adapted to our wit's end by film nerd Wes Anderson and fellow director Noah Baumbach from a Roald Dahl children's story, FANTASTIC MR. FOX is such a joyous movie viewing experience that my face hurt when its all-too-brief running time came to an end. I was smiling that much.

Wes Anderson is a well-loved director in film snob circles, but I have to confess that, until now, I've always appreciated and respected him far more than I've ever enjoyed him. His filmscapes are so meticulously created down to the finest detail that they have felt vacuum-sealed, devoid of air. His quirky characters have all circulated in worlds of white, Holden Caulfield-like privilege: boarding schools, families detached by their own wealth, pasttimes of the rich. I have always had a hard time getting into these stories, and yet I've always noticed a genius comic timing and a batch of discussion-worthy, quirky and insecure characters absent from the majority of films in need of them.

FANTASTIC MR. FOX has all of the comic timing and quirkiness, but this time, Anderson focus his anal-retentive eye for details on the art of stop motion, to the point where he slows down the film's frames-per-second to specifically draw attention to the medium itself. The result is, frankly, pure genius. Tempered color palates and visual symbolisms, sly dialogue, symbolic mise-en-scene.

But this fox is truly a sly one. It is, at times, silly to the point of being giddy. It will remind audience, I'd suspect, of a Wallace and Gromit cartoon, with the misadventures of animals on display for humans to enjoy. But Anderson takes even further the notion that we are truly spying on the animals' world. These are not Disney animals, made to personify human character traits. Rather, they are busy and fussy creatures who are irritated by us humans, and they are no longer willing to sit by idly without doing something about it.

For those who don't know the basic story, Mr. Fox used to pull off some sneaky heists in his day but is now a domesticated father and husband who welcomes his nephew for an extended vision. But - as the film reminds us more than once - he is still a wild animal, and his urges have never left him. One more heist, he insists. The classic heist film convention...this is my last one. So Fox rounds up a few helpers but unloads a ridiculous plan. The heist will be three-pronged, seeking revenge on not one but three local farmers who have in some way or another terrorized the local animals.

Played by George Clooney, who does little to affect a different cadence or sound than the George Clooney of any other film he's in, is perfectly dry here, resulting in gut-splitting hilarity in moments such as when Anderson and Baumbach replace the typical foul language of adults with the word "cuss." The joke never got old. Clooney inserts "cuss" in every part of a sentence just as we creatively use the f-word today.

The rest of the vocal cast is equally great, with Meryl Streep (what a year for her!) as Mrs. Fox, Jason Schwartzman (an Anderson staple) as their son, Ash, and Bill Murray (another Anderson favorite) as a badger.

The script is Award-worthy. It is ridiculously clever to a fault, pure joy from start to finish. I can't type enough superlatives about it. Nor can I do justice in words to compliment what was clearly a daunting feat of artistic direction. As with all Anderson creations, the images in the film don't exist simply to tell the story. They are pictures to be mined for information on repeat viewings, rich with symbolism and cultural psychology.

I would have to say that FANTASTIC MR. FOX was not only my favorite animated film of the year, but perhaps one of my favorite films, period. It has made me want to dive back into the Anderson filmography and, perhaps, give some of his stuffy, formalist comedies another shot.

Were you planning to skip this one? The cuss you are! See it NOW. You will fall in love, too.

Wes Anderson's films are traditionally quirky and full of complex themes, and his adaptation of Roald Dahl's Fantastic Mr. Fox is no different. Don't be fooled by the fact that it's animated (stop motion); this material is not targeted at children.

When we join the story, Mrs. Fox (Streep) is telling Mr. Fox (Clooney) that she's pregnant. The two proceed to rob a chicken farm and narrowly escape capture. Mrs. Fox makes him promise to look for other work now that they are about to become parents. Mr. Fox agrees and finds a job writing a newspaper column.

Mr. Fox settles down in his new life, but always regrets giving up his old ways. He's also tired of living in a hole in the ground and wants a better home for his family. He goes to see Badger (Murray), who advises him about properties for sale in the area. Fox wants a house near three local farms, but Badger suggests that the neighborhood is too dangerous. The local children even have a rhyme about the farmers:

Boggis, Bunce and Bean
One fat, one short, one lean
These horrible crooks
So different in looks
Were nonetheless equally mean

Fox is aware of the danger, but yearns for his former chicken-stealing days. As Anderson regularly reminds us, these are wild animals. Fox can't deny his nature and buys the new house so that he can be close to the three farms.

His decision goes directly against his promise to his wife and that was his first mistake.

There's a lot of humor in the film, but it's generally quite subtle. The family sits down to eat dinner and they eat like wild animals. The food is gone in seconds. Their son, Ash, is moody and craves attention from his father. He spits on the floor when he's angry or disappointed and he clearly has problems. When his cousin Kristofferson comes to stay, the situation worsens. Fox seems to favor Kristofferson over his own son and compliments him constantly.

Forget that we're dealing with animals for a moment and think about the story. If that happened in a regular movie, we would be dealing with a typical family drama. Husband and wife break promises and have trust issues, while their son is being raised by parents who don't understand him. This is not the kind of story that small children would understand, although some of the scenes are funny and contain action that would appeal to a child.

Fox enlists the help of Kylie Opossum and the two steal chickens from Boggis. The action is typical animated fare and the way the two sneak around is funny. They lace blueberries with a sedative to get past the dogs and the way the dogs react is also funny. They successfully steal from Bunce and plan to stop once they steal cider from Bean. For the final robbery, Ash wants to come along. Fox won't let him, but allows Kristofferson to take part. He seems to have very little idea that such a decision could hurt his son's feelings.

The robberies are fun to watch, especially when the animals wear bandit hats. It reminds me of the robbery in Bottle Rocket when the participants decide to wear similar hats even though their victims have already seen their faces.

Ash yearns to be an athlete and wants to emulate his father's success at Whack-Bat (a game which parodies cricket). Kristofferson is a balanced individual who regularly meditates and knows karate. Ash is extremely jealous of his cousin and his ability to win his father's approval.

The three robberies annoy the farmers, so Bean (Gambon) decides to organize the trio and plans to kill Fox. This is where the film starts to take on a more serious tone. Mrs. Fox discovers that her husband has been lying to her and scratches his face in a fit of temper. This scene annoyed one of my friends who expected the film to be lighthearted and suitable for the whole family. Mrs. Fox acts like the wild animal she is. There's another scene in which one of the animals is maimed. Although it's presented in a humorous way, it could disturb people.

The remainder of the film deals with the three farmers finding ways to threaten the existence of Fox and his friends. They escape by tunneling deeper, but face the threat of starvation if they don't find a solution. Some of the other animals resent Fox for putting them in such a dangerous situation.

There's considerable peril which could worry small children, and a lot of humor which would probably fly over their heads. It was only given a PG-rating, but be aware that not every child will like this harsh world. The animals are true to their nature.

The reason I like the film so much is the style of humor. Like Bottle Rocket and The Darjeeling Limited, the characters speak with a sense of irony or sarcasm and most of the humor is tongue-in-cheek. It feels similar to Tarantino or the Coen brothers at times. There's no swearing, but every character uses the word "cuss" in situations in which they would normally swear. I found that particularly funny. One animal questions why a ransom note was made using words cut out of a magazine when everyone already knew the identities of the kidnappers. That's also funny to me. The missions all have elaborate titles and remind me of the way Tarantino uses chapters in his stories.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is an exercise in style. Mr. Fox himself is very stylish, dressing smartly and using his trademark whistle when he thinks he's being clever or cool. Clooney was a great choice for the part and the other actors all do a good job too.

The story is essentially about a dysfunctional family and shows how Ash attempts to come to terms with his existence. Will Mr. Fox eventually become a better father? Will Ash grow up and take responsibility for his own actions? Do Mr. and Mrs. Fox strengthen their marriage, or will the trust issues tear them apart? There's a lot going on beneath the surface.

Wes Anderson directs a visually remarkable adaptation of Roald Dahl's children's story Fantastic Mr. Fox. It's funny how I never read that book when I was a child; I was more akin to the world of Willy Wonka or the discombobulated domestic abuse of The Twits. But Dahl certainly had a style of extravagant surrealism and almost frightening hyperbole. In Fantastic Mr. Fox, the scenario is no different. Combined with Anderson's zest for black humor, this is one animated film that I'm proud to say pays homage to Dahl's legacy. 

The story follows the sly Mr. Fox (cynically voiced by George Clooney) who promises his wife, Felicity, that he'll subside from a life of larceny and settle down in the farmland world. This is of course all highly fabricated. Animals cannot drive motorcycles, eat breakfast cereal, or pen columns in the local gazette. But this is Roald Dahl, not Watership Down. It appears that Anderson was truly compelled by Dahl's universe; he never pulls the punches for a second. The farmland animals are brought to life by an all-star cast, and fortunately that talent shines through. Bill Murray makes a hilarious badger, and Anderson regular Owen Wilson shines in a cameo as a gym teacher. There's also this possum named Kylie who was probably one of the finest examples of comic relief I've seen in a while. I'm still not sure what his loony eyes mean...

There's a zaniness that pervades  this film and it is not one to be trifled with. Every movement, breath, and idiosyncrasy is heightened by the stop-motion puppetry. There's a particularly evil triumvirate of farmers whom Mr. Fox rattles, and while their villainy is gratuitous, it is appropriate in this story. It's interesting to hear Michael Gambon grimace and grovel in a voice I had previously established only as the kindred Dumbledore. 

Fantastic Mr. Fox is not entirely without flaws. The protagonist himself, because he is a fox, has little redeeming qualities. He admits that he's flawed but his species prevents him from learning from any mistake. For a children's story, I'm not quite sure what sort of message is trying to be conveyed here. The progressive absurdity that ensues (like rescuing fox Kristofferson from an attic) occasionally falls victim to petty gags. But Anderson's visuals are ubiquitous. They never cease to impress. 

Fantastic Mr. Fox is a hilarious black comedy that adds a witticism to a children's story. For that reason, I think both adult and child audiences can find resonance in it. The children are sure to get a laugh out of the slapstick humor, the extravagant visuals, and the movement of the characters. As for the adults, they'll be asking themselves, "What the cuss was that?"

This very well might have been my favorite movie from 2009. Visually stunning stop-start animation. Quirky, charmingly strange and somewhat random.
 
What is so amazing is that the stop-start technique (the most ridged and calculated filming method in history) can feel so improvised and genuine. The dialogue is second to none, and it encapsulates any emotion you can think of. It is hilarious in its odd and unique script one scene, and emotional and heartfelt in the next.
 
Preaches a message of individuality and persistence. While this is categorized as a children's film, this is just as much for adults as anyone. Highly highly recommended.

Wes Anderson's take on Roald Dahl's classic boasts unique animation and a nice retro feel. The story has no problem getting from start to finish, making this one of the quickest animated films out there. Unfortunately, the film's dry sense of humor gets in the way of the story. The characters are likable, but the film lacks heart. While many critics have praised the film for being "heartwarming" and "touching", the film was actually kind of hollow. The attempts at adding character development work, but they ultimately make the film slow down. The father-son relationship seemed rushed, but the relationship between the son (Ash) and his cousin (Kristofferson) was a nice subplot. Aside from those flaws, "Fantastic Mr. Fox" has a lot going for it. The art direction captures the autumnal setting of the film, and the character designs are creative. The scenes where Fox and Kylie steal from the three farmers are exciting and well-conceived. The soundtrack is a nice mix, including some 60s rock. (Although The Beach Boys' "Heroes and Villains" has nothing to do with foxes stealing squabs on a farm, ditto The Rolling Stones' "Street Fighting Man", which was used on the scene where the farmers use tractors to dig out Fox's burrow) It's a very quirky film and it gets a lot right, but the story needed a little work. Otherwise, it's a creative film that deserves recognition.

This is a rare gem in modern cinema, being filmed in stop motion animation. Using stop motion sets it apart from other recent animated features that rely more on CGI,  this choice adds to the effect of the adventures of a fox that tries to fight against his own thieving nature. The animation techniques used in this film are reminiscent of cartoonish, technically sophisticated Ray Harryhausen, offering smoother movements and better character integration with the backgrounds. From a technical standpoint the style very effectively matches the story, sound effects are comedic and appropriate, lighting is appropriate for mood, and the effects are suitable to the movie's fantastic nature. 

Vocal casting is overall well done. I loved George Clooney as the voice of Mr. Fox who adds a feeling of "smooth" cockiness while maintaining the ability to garner the audience's sympathy when needed. In all, this is an enjoyable film of an impulsive fox and the prices he and others must pay for his actions and it's well worth watching.

Wes Anderson not only proves himself yet again as an auteur, but that he also has a knack for animation, because Fantastic Mr. Fox is nothing short of fantastic. Fans who are worried about this peculiar transition in Anderson's career need not be, as his stamp is surely on everything. 

We are entertained with a light-hearted and playful story that remains always faithful to the children's book and the great Roald Dahl's vision, wild and quirky characters, and a beautiful setting bustling with imagination. Mix in the clever and often hilarious dialogue, all the heists, bandit hats being passed around--or the modified tube sock substitute--and you have a movie of pure delight that anyone of any age can enjoy immensely. I could not take my eyes away from the screen, and maintained a smile all the while. 

It's refreshing to see George Clooney take on the voice of the sly and spunky Mr. Fox, as opposed to his more numerous, Oscar-praised performances, and who better to follow his lead than the most talented and most respected Meryl Streep as his wife, Mrs. Fox. If that doesn't have you yearning to see it, there's also Billy Murray as Badger and Mr. Fox's lawyer, Wallace Wolodarsky (who wrote for The Simpsons during the first four seasons) as Kylie the opossum and Mr. Fox's partner in crime, Jason Schwartzman as Mr. Fox's son, Ash, who spits whenever he is annoyed and is constantly trying to get his father's approval, and a nice surprise by Willem Dafoe as Rat, the night watchman of the alcoholic cider. Owen Wilson has a small role as Coach Skip--Hotbox!--and Wes Anderson even lends his voice. It's just an overall fun time watching Mr. Fox and friends use their specialties to stop three conglomerate farmers from destroying their homes; and why not off with some poultry and cider along the way? 

Fantastic Mr. Fox is a stop-motion romp that has endless personality and vigor and is a feast for the eyes. Pixar's Up is going to have major competition for awards this year, and I'm rooting for something different. With dry humor the likes of The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou, and the craziness of The Royal Tenenbaums, Wes Anderson has incorporated his style into every aspect of this movie, making it the best animated feature of the year. What the cuss are you waiting for? See it!

Let me get this out of the way. "Fantastic Mr. Fox" is one of the best animated films I've ever seen.It does what all films seek to do, by creating a unique and appealing world, and populating that world with a wealth of, for lack of a better term, fantastic characters.

The film is based on a book by Roald Dahl, whose works include "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," "The BFG," and "The Witches." The major plot points of the film are roughly corollary to those of the novel, but the film is a Wes Anderson joint, through and through. Mr. Fox (George Clooney) is a reformed bird thief turned newspaper man, who despite a devotion to his wife and son, yearns for the excitement of his glory days. When the fox family moves into their new home (tree) near three prominent farms, Fox decides to embark upon one last heist.The Fox family dynamic is altered by the arrival of Mrs. Fox's nephew Kristofferson (Eric Anderson) who lodges in the Fox home while his father battles "double-pneumonia." Fox's twleve-fox-year-old son Ash (Jason Schwartzman) is jealous of Kristofferson's talents and stature, and his father's blatant admiration thereof. As Fox squares off against the three sinister farmers, Boggis, Bunce and Bean, and tries to hide his illicit activities from his suspicious wife, (Meryl Streep) Ash struggles to outshine Kristofferson and makes his father proud.

The plot is whimsical and exciting, but as in all of Anderson's work, what really shines are the characters. Each is beautifully animated and brought to life by wonderful voice work by a cast including Bill Murray, Adrian Brody, Owen Wilson, Willem Dafoe, and Michael Gambon.

The dialogue is hip and crisp without being gimmicky, and the timing of the interactions is pitch-perfect. There are some poignant moments, as well as some that made me laugh aloud.You'll find yourself quoting this movie for days. It's rife with brilliant and bizarre one-liners.

Even if you've never seen any of Anderson's work, including "The Royal Tenenbaums," and "Rushmore," you'll immediately identify his offbeat aesthetic. Fantastic Mr. Fox is made using stop motion animation, but Anderson's lovable visual trademarks are all here - deliberate and methodical cinematography, vintage style, vibrant color, and prominent on-screen typography. The construction of the characters and sets is charming and novel, and every frame features a stimulating palette of color and texture.

Rounding out the experience is a raucously excellent soundtrack, featuring The Rolling Stones, The Wellington, and Burl Ives. There's even an original tune by the on-screen avatar of Jarvis Cocker. The mix of off-kilter animation and washy 60s rock is a pure delight.

I don't have much in terms of summation here, guys. Every element of the "Fantastic Mr. Fox" is fantastic, and the final product is nearly without flaw. It's poignant, funny, and a joy to behold. Simply put, it's one of Anderson's best. See this movie, folks. You won't regret it.

Stop motion is a curious art.  It never looks as real as CGI, and it's not as fluid as CGI.  Also, it's extremely difficult to master.  In fact, one would wonder why anyone would bother making a stop motion movie, as opposed to a CGI movie.  The reason, is that stop motion has an odd, old fashioned, hand made feel to it.  And somehow, that feel has been captured and placed into this movie, and it's not just evident in the animation.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is inspired from Roald Dahl's picture book by the same name.  The film follows the story of Mr. Fox, who starts stealing farmer's merchandise again, without telling his wife.  Mr. Fox has been planning some "great heist," despite his promises to his wife, claiming he would quit.  Soon, the three meanest farmers of them all (Farmers Boggis, Bunce, and Bean), decide to end Mr. Fox's reign once and for all.

The film's dry humor is both witty and hilarious.  No movie in the world can stand up to the unique humor that Fantastic Mr. Fox displays.  

I give points to the outstanding voice talents (namely for George Clooney and Meryl Streep), and the comedic score by Alexandre Desplat.

The animation is spectacular.  By far the best I've seen in a stop motion film.  It's truly fantastic.  Even for stop motion, it looks incredibly good fashioned, and that is a very good thing.

Unlike the book, however, this is not a piece of entertainment I can recommend for younger children.  It's too dark, and they probably won't get many of the jokes (they may get a kick out of all the fuzzy animals, however).  This is more of an older kids and parents flick.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is fun, entertaining, unique, and visually wonderful.  It is not hard to understand why they call it "Fantastic" Mr. Fox.

A great first timer for Wes Anderson, animation is always exceptionally hard to get accurate. Anderson deserves credit as I'm told it was his first time, directing an animated feature. It combines subtle humour, with a well chosen form of cinematography, which makes this film suitable for not only children but also for adults.

The humor was very subtle. I really enjoy that type of humor. It's the type of humor in which you find yourself the only person laughing at a certain joke or action. This movie really highlighted that humor, which is what I appreciated. Thank you, Wes Anderson!

Filmmakers not only craft a brilliant story, they focus on the little details as well (Ash's way of describing how he's "different", Clooney's newspaper article, etc.).  In a word, the film is - fantastic.  Okay...what ELSE could I say?  :-)
This was a pretty cool/fun movie. It was a little odd, but in a good way and the claymation was beautifully done. Great movie for the whole family.

To explain how I felt about the movie, here are all the questions I asked myself during the movie, with not all of them being good. "Why is the animation so freaky?", "Why do they have so many close ups of the freaky animation?", "Why does Eric Anderson sound like Jesse Eisenberg?", "Are we really supposed to feel sorry for a rat that tries to kill 2 or 3 characters?", "Why does George Clooney's voice sound like sandpaper half the time?", "What's with those annoying subtitles?", "Why does the word cuss have to be used every two seconds?", and finally "Why does that horrible song with the kids chanting in this movie, let alone twice?". Even though there were even more questions that I didn't mention here, I did that so I could get to the point. After this movie was over, I was thinking about giving it a bad review, but then I thought "Hey, I think I like this movie!". I don't know if it was the clever jokes, the likable characters, or it's cheesy nature, but I knew that I wouldn't live with myself if I gave this a bad review. It's just.... likable. Sure, it has plenty of flaws, but aren't you forgetting the most important thing a movie can offer? Answer: Entertainment. So, if you want a movie with talking animals, creepy puppets, but something you and your kids can enjoy, I think you should rent this right away.
Just as much a visual spectacle as the beloved Nightmare Before Christmas, with staggering wit and excellent characters. A treat for all ages.

Easily one of my favorite animated movies of all time, Anderson outdoes himself with an all star cast, a great soundtrack (as usual), a great expansion on Roald Dahl story. Equally fun for adults an children.
Great movie for viewers of all ages.  A Wes Anderson flick based on a Roald Dahl book.

I think they got this one right; although I haven't actually read the book, it is very Roald Dahl-ish. Not your typical kids' animated film, but definitely funny (in an off sort of way). Has a weird seventies vibe for some reason, though...
worst take on this book ever! Nothing the same!!!
Good story about a person's true nature...

I like how it's different from other movies, but I couldn't help but be bored throughout the entire thing. I loved all of the voice actors, but I just didn't find anything funny in this movie. And parents: Don't let the stop-motion fool you into thinking it's a children's movie, because it is definitley not.

Right from the get go this movie blew me away.  Starting with a fox under a tree listening to the old Davey Crocket theme, and quickly going into one of my favorite Brian Wilson, Beach Boys tunes!  This movie was a total package from music to the casting.  Let's not forget about the animation which was very refreshing and engaging to watch.  The relationships of the characters were balanced just right that they were fun to watch, but were not over done or forced.   Mr. Fox's charm and personality came through as he was caught up in situation after situation.  The creativity of the film was great, when it came to eating, fighting, and their use of strong language.  the way they used the animation to work for them instead of trying to make things too perfect.  I thought the film did pretty much everything just right, except it slowed down at parts too much, for a little too long.  Although I think I'm just trying to find some flaw so I have an excuse to not give it 5 stars.  I was also happy to see Jarvis Cocker ("Pulp" frontman) make an appearance (Petey), as a song man and adding a bit of music.  Not to mention other songs that made cameos by The Rolling Stones, the Dave Fuller Four, and more Beach Boys!  My ears give this movie a 5 star rating for sure!  I'm not sure what took me so long to see this movie, but I'm very glad I did.  It might be a bit over the top for young kids to get the dialogue and some of the jokes, but I think they'll just enjoy some of the visuals and silliness that comes and goes.  I think this movie can speak to most age groups and will leave everyone pretty satisfied.
Haha marvelous, an instant classic!

I loved the vintage feel of the animation, but this was perhaps a litle too much in love with its own cleverness. I guess they reckoned the bizarre would offset the cuteness of the animation, but I felt that it was teetering a bit too close to the edge of overly weird.

Thanks to the genius of Pixar, animation has been a front runner in originality and quality, but not even those digital kings can outwit or even out-entertain this decade's animation godsend...Fantastic Mr. Fox

Based on the popular Roald Dahl children's box, Fantastic Mr. Fox follows a sly fox who steals from three very successful farmers, only to be hunted down to the point his nephew gets kidnapped. With the help of some fellow critters, Mr. Fox and his merry gang of rodents unleash a plan of revenge. 

If you couldn't tell from the trailers, Fantastic Mr. Fox is unlike anything out there. It's use of claymation and stop-animation is simply breathtaking, especially in an age of CGI powerhouses. One downside I have is the fact the humor, hilarious as it is, is far too dry or far too high brow for kids to enjoy this. They are better off sticking with Toy Story or something, but if you are old enough to get this film...you will be in for a treat.

I absolutely adored this film. I can't describe how much I enjoyed it actually. I was literally smiling the entire time from just sheer enjoyment. I laughed constantly and left that film feeling more than satisfied. This is one of the most entertaining films I have ever seen, animation or not. If you can handle its style of humor and its visuals, you are in for one of the most amazing films I have seen this decade. Fantastic Mr. Fox is simply...fantastic.
The Crack bat monologue is worth watching the entire movie
I didn't like this movie at all.

A definite change from today's standard CG animated movies.  Each of the voice actors in the movie give great performances but the character that sticks out is the musical score that goes along amazingly with the movie.  Simply put, this movie is fantastic.
One of the best animated treats for the eyes along with a witty story, it's unfortunate it will always come in 2nd to Pixar's Up for best animated of 2009
One of the more enjoyable movies of 2009.

Stop Motion Animated films always fascinates me. To me, it's always fun to watch clay or puppets moving about and living their own lives. I simply love it. Fantastic Mr. Fox is based on Roald Dahl children's novel of the same name about Mr Fox and how he outwits his farmer neighbours to steal their food from right under their noses.
The stop motion animation effects used in the film were superb and really fun to just watch. The environment and characters looks were made so realistic, their fur and eyes, probably everything were so detailed. 
The movie's plot focuses more on Mr. Fox's relationship to Mrs. Fox and his son, which is pitted against Mr. Fox's desire to steal chickens as a means of feeling like his natural self. The movie adds scenes before Mr. Fox attacks the three farmers and after their bulldozing of the hill, as well as a slightly altered ending and more background on Mr. Fox's past life as a thief.
Development on the project began in 2004 as collaboration between Anderson and Henry Selick (who worked with Anderson on the 2004 film The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou) under Revolution Studios. In 2007 Revolution folded, Selick left to direct Coraline, and work on the film moved to 20th Century Fox. Production began in London in 2007. This film is also director Wes Anderson's first animated film and first film adaptation. Wes Anderson did an amazing job in directing this visually beautiful picture that left me impressed knowing that this is his first time working on an animated film and more amazed, in stop motion animation. Great work indeed. Anderson directed it with a great sense  and reveals his own style of story-telling with animation, it is just entertaining from start to end. I don't find myself getting bored of the film at all, the direction and animation will keep your eyes glued on the movie all the way, and that is all that matters. 
Voice acting in the film was absolutely great. Hands down. George Clooney voiced as Mr. Fox, great voice acting performance given out by the Academy Award Winning Actor. I personally find that Clooney is the best choice for the voice of Mr. Fox. Meryl Streep voice as Mrs. Felicity Fox, Mr. Foxs' wife. All voice acting performances were great. Nothing to point out on it. Other voice actors includes, Jason Schwartzman, Eric Chase Anderson, Wallace Wolodarsky, Bill Murray, Willem Dafoe, Owen Wilson and Michael Gambon.
I am impressed throughout the whole movie. I am pretty sure that anybody would be, when they watch this family friendly adventure film. Fantastic Mr. Fox is a beautiful film that has a variety of elements in it which includes, friendship, love and adventure. One of the best animated films I have watched in a while. Fantastic Mr. Fox is a 90% FRESH for me. Visually stunning stop motion effects, amazing directing by Wes Anderson and great voice acting performances by it's cast. A great animation film to enjoy for one and all. :)
I never liked this kind of stick-figure-like animation, but it didn't really bother me in "Fantastic Mr. Fox". The characters were very enjoyable and something was always going on. :)
One of my favorite movies. Amazing in every way.
Love this! Think I've seen it about 5 times now. The animation is gorgeous!
I absolutely loved this!
It was quirky and new and visually interesting - I enjoyed it!
I was laughing the whole way through. This movie is witty and smart and not at all what i was expecting.
I'm watching it for the second time!
Fantastic character design and brilliant musical score - this film never got boring. Highly recommendable!

Once again, I love it when people tell me to see a movie (not suggest, but TELL me), and this one came from my little sister. I knew it would be decent, but not as good as I thought it would be. I loved it.
Yeah... didn't care for this so much.  The animation was amazing, but didn't care for the story itself so much.  Ah well, can't be one of the masses all the time!
A good cast helps this funny, family friendly movie give some smiles and an enjoyable time.

This is easily now one of my favorite films. It is a classic Roald Dahl story. The man who wrote Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, Willy Wonka, James and the Giant Peach, Matilda, and many more. Wes Anderson as always did a great job with the screenplay and the directing as well.

The character were well developed and the story was expanded to such a higher level than one could have imagined. With an amazing cast consisting of Clooney, Streep, Schwartzman, Murray, and Dafoe just to name a few.

Anderson has made something that will last in my memory forever. Most people see animation purely as an outlet for children. This film, while I would let a child watch it, is much more adult in my eyes. Both the child and the adult in you will love this for different reasons.

He did things in this film that I have never seen done with stop motion. There are amazing shots that will take your breath away. Beautiful sets that you can tell took so much time to make. He has outdone himself on this film.

If you haven't seen this yet then this is a must see. I know I plan to go out and buy it the next chance I get and I'm sure many others will as well after seeing this.

Why you should watch it? Because this ain't Pixar. This one's slightly better.

Wes Anderson is known for making smart, quick witted films with great dialogue and wonderfully casts, like The Royal Tenenbaums and Rushmore. Fantastic Mr. Fox is Anderson's first attempt at stop motion animation and is a smart, quick witted film with great dialogue and a wonderfully cast. It was also nominated for two Academy Awards and numerous others. 

The voices are phenomenal. Clooney, Streep, Murray, Schwartzman, and Anderson himself. Voices weren't just filmed in a sound studio. They were creative in their choices and tried, successfully in my opinion, to capture their true environment. A lot of it was recorded outdoors. 

Anderson was also very smart about gathering a crew to make his film. He recruited the same people who did Tim Burton's The Corpse Bride. It was a great choice. He supposedly acted out how he wanted the scenes to look on his I-Phone and sent them to his animators. Stop animation can be pretty boring when it's not really creative. But with a good enough story and sound, it can be successful and make the animation that much better. 

They even had some fun with making it, as the tacky brown suede suit worn by Mr. Fox is from actual material from one of Wes Anderson's suits. 

The Fantastic Mr. Fox didn't get enough publicity and wasn't seen by enough people, I'd say. It's a fun movie that's definitely worth a rent.

Yeah, probably my favorite animated movie. This is a complete delight, Wes Anderson expands his mediums while retaining his stylistics. Anderson has never been a cookie cutter or assembly line director, he has kept his esoteric style and humor beginning with his first gem Bottle Rocket. He is aquatinted with co-writer Noah Baumbach who co-wrote The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou and afterward directed The Squid and the Whale. And in Fantastic Mr. Fox Anderson's style is emulated and even made better by the stop-motion animation. The tale follows Mr. Fox, (Clooney) a professional chicken and squab -whatever that is- thief who continuously goes on runs with his wife Felicity (Streep). On one occasion they are both trapped in a fox trap and Felicity reveals she is pregnant, and demands that Mr. Fox promises her to give up his current profession if they escape so they can settle down. Mr. Fox does settle down with his family, but the urge to get back to his old ways progresses then eventually spills over, and thats when the 'cluster-cuss' begins.
	The movie is less successful at being a children's movie, but is very successful at being a crowd pleaser. The humor could be too high brow for some kids, but they will be entertained by the vivid imagery and the ambient characters. Adults would most likely enjoy the wit and charm in the writing as well a the performances by the voice actors. A higher admiration can be held  for the amazingly detailed and unique set pieces and stop-motion.      
	 The usual Anderson suspects are here as well and they serve to season the Anderson flavor and put distinction into their characters. Jason Shwartzman voices Ash, Mr. Foxes son who is inept at sports and puts all his effort into becoming an athlete, while competing in the spotlight with his cousin Kristofferson (Eric Anderson) for his fathers attention. Shwartzman infuses the 'snarkyness' and quirky wit that made his character from Anderson's Rushmore so appealing. This movie is a interwoven gem through out and it's rare to see movies like these anymore as stop-motion is a rarely directed medium. 
Yep, High fives all around Mr. Anderson and Mr. Baumbach.

Why is he wearing that bandit hat?

Mr. Fox is a cunning fellow that enjoys stealing chickens until the day he discovers the love of his life is pregnant.  Mr. Fox agrees to settle down with Mrs. Fox and stop stealing chickens.  Ten to twelve years after the agreement, the fox child is a teenager and Mr. Fox decides it is time to begin his old hobby of stealing chickens again.  Once Mr. Fox starts robbing the local farmers and indirectly puts his family and township at risk.    

"Why'd you take your shoes off?"
"So I don't break your nose when I kick it."

Wes Anderson, director of Bottle Rocket, Rushmore, The Royal Tenenbaums, The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou, The Darjeeling Limited, and the upcoming Moonrise Kingdom, delivers The Fantastic Mr. Fox.  The storyline for this picture is wonderfully original for this genre and a breath of fresh air in animated pictures.   The voices are well selected and include George Clooney, Meryl Streep, Bill Murray, Owen Wilson, and Willem Dafoe.

"In the end, we all die unless you change."

I came across this picture while flicking through the channels and decided to give it a shot.  We watched this picture as a family and found the animation style very entertaining, the script clever, and the overall premise worthwhile.  This is a unique picture that is entertaining for all ages.  I strongly recommend seeing this picture.

"Tails don't grow back."

Grade: A
